      Cycling of a quinone-bromide flow battery for large-scale electrochemical energy storage
      Huskinson, Brian; Marshak, Michael P.; Gerhardt, Michael R.; Aziz, Michael J.
      ECS Transactions (2014), 61 (37, Stationary and Large Scale Electrical Energy Storage Systems 4), 27-30CODEN: ECSTF8; ISSN:1938-5862. (Electrochemical Society)
      We have demonstrated the performance of an aq. redox flow battery composed of a neg. electrode consisting of a redox couple between anthraquinone di-sulfonate and its corresponding hydroquinone, and a pos. electrode consisting of a redox couple between hydrobromic acid and bromine. The peak power d. is approx. 0.6 W/cm2. After 750 deep cycles, the av. discharge capacity retention is 99.84% per cycle and the av. current efficiency is 98.35%.

      Asperger, S. Kinetics of the decomposition of potassium ferrocyanide in ultra-violet light. Trans. Faraday Soc. 1952, 48, 617– 624,  DOI: 10.1039/TF9524800617

      154
      Kinetics of the decomposition of potassium ferrocyanide in ultraviolet light
      Asperger, S.
      Transactions of the Faraday Society (1952), 48 (), 617-24CODEN: TFSOA4; ISSN:0014-7672.
      The kinetics of both the decompn. and the reverse (thermal) reaction were investigated in presence of air, in N, and in O with a glass electrode for detn. of pH. Oxygen has no influence. The reaction scheme involving the formation of Fe(CN)5.H2O3- is in accord with the expts. The addn. of K3Fe(CN)6 inhibits the reaction. In the light the process has a neg. temp. coeff. (Q10 = 0.7). The energy of activation of the reverse process (reaction between Fe(CN)5.H2O3- and CN-), is about 24 kcal./mole. Fe(CN)5.H2O3- is decompd. by prolonged exposure to light, but this process is very slow. The dependence of the initial velocity of the process on the concn. of the K4Fe(CN)6, however, shows that the decompn. is due not only to the light energy, but also to collisions of mols.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      1. 1
        IPCC Climate Change 2014: Synthesis Report; IPCC, 2014.

      2. 2
        Raupach, M. R.; Marland, G.; Ciais, P.; Le Quere, C.; Canadell, J. G.; Klepper, G.; Field, C. B. Global and regional drivers of accelerating CO2 emissions. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2007, 104, 10288– 10293,  DOI: 10.1073/pnas.0700609104
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        2
        Global and regional drivers of accelerating CO2 emissions
        Raupach, Michael R.; Marland, Gregg; Ciais, Philippe; Le Quere, Corinne; Canadell, Josep G.; Klepper, Gernot; Filed, Christopher B.
        Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America (2007), 104 (24), 10288-10293CODEN: PNASA6; ISSN:0027-8424. (National Academy of Sciences)
        CO2 emissions from fossil-fuel burning and industrial processes have been accelerating at a global scale, with their growth rate increasing from 1.1% yr-1 for 1990-1999 to >3% yr-1 for 2000-2004. The emissions growth rate since 2000 was greater than for the most fossil-fuel intensive of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change emissions scenarios developed in the late 1990s. Global emissions growth since 2000 was driven by a cessation or reversal of earlier declining trends in the energy intensity of gross domestic product (GDP) (energy/GDP) and the carbon intensity of energy (emissions/energy), coupled with continuing increases in population and per-capita GDP. Nearly const. or slightly increasing trends in the carbon intensity of energy have been recently obsd. in both developed and developing regions. No region is decarbonizing its energy supply. The growth rate in emissions is strongest in rapidly developing economies, particularly China. Together, the developing and least-developed economies (forming 80% of the world's population) accounted for 73% of global emissions growth in 2004 but only 41% of global emissions and only 23% of global cumulative emissions since the mid-18th century. The results have implications for global equity.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXmvVCmsL0%253D&md5=b926ccd4db41a6b0b3ffdc8af6052173
      3. 3
        Pacala, S.; Socolow, R. Stabilization Wedges: Solving the Climate Problem for the Next 50 Years with Current Technologies. Science 2004, 305, 968– 971,  DOI: 10.1126/science.1100103
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        3
        Stabilization Wedges: Solving the Climate Problem for the Next 50 Years with Current Technologies
        Pacala, S.; Socolow, R.
        Science (Washington, DC, United States) (2004), 305 (5686), 968-972CODEN: SCIEAS; ISSN:0036-8075. (American Association for the Advancement of Science)
        A review. Humanity already possesses the fundamental scientific, tech., and industrial know-how to solve the carbon and climate problem for the next half-century. A portfolio of technologies now exists to meet the world's energy needs over the next 50 yr and limit atm. CO2 to a trajectory that avoids a doubling of the preindustrial concn. Every element in this portfolio has passed beyond the lab. bench and demonstration project; many are already implemented somewhere at full industrial scale. Although no element is a credible candidate for doing the entire job (or even half the job) by itself, the portfolio as a whole is large enough that not every element has to be used.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2cXmsVGmt78%253D&md5=48e4d84210675d7e9aa644cac8eb6c4a

      7. 7
        Lisbona, D.; Snee, T. A review of hazards associated with primary lithium and lithium-ion batteries. Process Saf. Environ. Prot. 2011, 89, 434– 442,  DOI: 10.1016/j.psep.2011.06.022
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        7
        A review of hazards associated with primary lithium and lithium-ion batteries
        Lisbona, Diego; Snee, Timothy
        Process Safety and Environmental Protection (2011), 89 (6), 434-442CODEN: PSEPEM; ISSN:0957-5820. (Elsevier B.V.)
        A review. Primary lithium batteries contain hazardous materials such as lithium metal and flammable solvents, which can lead to exothermic activity and runaway reactions above a defined temp. Lithium-ion batteries operating outside the safe envelope can also lead to formation of lithium metal and thermal runaway. Despite protection by battery safety mechanisms, fires originating from primary lithium and lithium-ion batteries are a relatively frequent occurrence. This paper reviews the hazards assocd. with primary lithium and lithium-ion cells, with an emphasis on the role played by chem. at individual cell level. Safety mechanisms to prevent the occurrence and limit the consequences of incidents are reviewed, together with safety tests to monitor compliance with battery safety regulations and stds. Incident information from news accounts and open literature sources are reviewed to ext. causal information. It is concluded that the potential severity of incidents during storage, transport and recycling of waste batteries can be significantly higher than in end-use applications. Safe storage, packaging and labeling practices, as well as communication among the parties involved, are essential to ensure safety across the battery lifecycle. It is recommended that a database of lithium battery incidents would be valuable to improve the evidence base for informing accident prevention measures.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XktlOhtA%253D%253D&md5=eae4cd86c3e7d6170e3c069e3eca8ee0
      8. 8
        Wang, Q.; Ping, P.; Zhao, X.; Chu, G.; Sun, J.; Chen, C. Thermal runaway caused fire and explosion of lithium ion battery. J. Power Sources 2012, 208, 210– 224,  DOI: 10.1016/j.jpowsour.2012.02.038
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        8
        Thermal runaway caused fire and explosion of lithium ion battery
        Wang, Qingsong; Ping, Ping; Zhao, Xuejuan; Chu, Guanquan; Sun, Jinhua; Chen, Chunhua
        Journal of Power Sources (2012), 208 (), 210-224CODEN: JPSODZ; ISSN:0378-7753. (Elsevier B.V.)
        A review of lithium-ion battery hazards, thermal runaway theory, basic reactions, thermal models, simulations and exptl. works. The general theory is proposed and detailed reactions are summarized, which include solid electrolyte interface decompn., anode active material and electrolyte reaction, cathode active material and electrolyte reaction, electrolyte decompn., and anode active material and binder reaction. The thermal models or electrochem.-thermal models include one-, two- and three-dimensional models, which can be simulated by finite element method and finite vol. method. The related prevention techniques are summarized and discussed on the inherent safety methods and safety device methods. Some perspectives and outlook on safety enhancement for lithium-ion batteries are proposed for the future development.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XltFyrsL0%253D&md5=b9521b848be87633adda7924a78f9e1c
      9. 9
        Li, Z.; Pan, M. S.; Su, L.; Tsai, P.-C.; Badel, A. F.; Valle, J. M.; Eiler, S. L.; Xiang, K.; Brushett, F. R.; Chiang, Y.-M. Air-Breathing Aqueous Sulfur Flow Battery for Ultralow-Cost Long-Duration Electrical Storage. Joule 2017, 1, 306– 327,  DOI: 10.1016/j.joule.2017.08.007
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        9
        Air-Breathing Aqueous Sulfur Flow Battery for Ultralow-Cost Long-Duration Electrical Storage
        Li, Zheng; Pan, Menghsuan Sam; Su, Liang; Tsai, Ping-Chun; Badel, Andres F.; Valle, Joseph M.; Eiler, Stephanie L.; Xiang, Kai; Brushett, Fikile R.; Chiang, Yet-Ming
        Joule (2017), 1 (2), 306-327CODEN: JOULBR; ISSN:2542-4351. (Cell Press)
        The intermittency of renewable electricity generation has created a pressing global need for low-cost, highly scalable energy storage. Although pumped hydroelec. storage (PHS) and underground compressed air energy storage (CAES) have the lowest costs today (∼US$100/kWh installed cost), each faces geog. and environmental constraints that may limit further deployment. Here, we demonstrate an ambient-temp. aq. rechargeable flow battery that uses low-cost polysulfide anolytes in conjunction with lithium or sodium counter-ions, and an air- or oxygen-breathing cathode. The soln. energy d., at 30-145 Wh/L depending on concn. and sulfur speciation range, exceeds current soln.-based flow batteries, and the cost of active materials per stored energy is exceptionally low, ∼US$1/kWh when using sodium polysulfide. The projected storage economics parallel those for PHS and CAES but can be realized at higher energy d. and with minimal locational constraints.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXpvFGhuro%253D&md5=8223ecab6c9a03beb3df417cc24bdf4c
      10. 10
        Darling, R. M.; Gallagher, K. G.; Kowalski, J. A.; Ha, S.; Brushett, F. R. Pathways to low-cost electrochemical energy storage: a comparison of aqueous and nonaqueous flow batteries. Energy Environ. Sci. 2014, 7, 3459– 3477,  DOI: 10.1039/C4EE02158D
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        10
        Pathways to low-cost electrochemical energy storage: a comparison of aqueous and nonaqueous flow batteries
        Darling, Robert M.; Gallagher, Kevin G.; Kowalski, Jeffrey A.; Ha, Seungbum; Brushett, Fikile R.
        Energy & Environmental Science (2014), 7 (11), 3459-3477CODEN: EESNBY; ISSN:1754-5706. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        Energy storage is increasingly seen as a valuable asset for electricity grids composed of high fractions of intermittent sources, such as wind power or, in developing economies, unreliable generation and transmission services. However, the potential of batteries to meet the stringent cost and durability requirements for grid applications is largely unquantified. We investigate electrochem. systems capable of economically storing energy for hours and present an anal. of the relationships among technol. performance characteristics, component cost factors, and system price for established and conceptual aq. and nonaq. batteries. We identified potential advantages of nonaq. flow batteries over those based on aq. electrolytes; however, new challenging constraints burden the nonaq. approach, including the soly. of the active material in the electrolyte. Requirements in harmony with economically effective energy storage are derived for aq. and nonaq. systems. The attributes of flow batteries are compared to those of aq. and nonaq. enclosed and hybrid (semi-flow) batteries. Flow batteries are a promising technol. for reaching these challenging energy storage targets owing to their independent power and energy scaling, reliance on facile and reversible reactants, and potentially simpler manuf. as compared to established enclosed batteries such as lead-acid or lithium-ion.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXhsFOlt7zL&md5=384d17bc3cd919262f3b73b94463236b
      11. 11
        Lin, K.; Chen, Q.; Gerhardt, M. R.; Tong, L.; Kim, S. B.; Eisenach, L.; Valle, A. W.; Hardee, D.; Gordon, R. G.; Aziz, M. J.; Marshak, M. P. Alkaline quinone flow battery. Science 2015, 349, 1529– 1532,  DOI: 10.1126/science.aab3033
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        11
        Alkaline quinone flow battery
        Lin, Kaixiang; Chen, Qing; Gerhardt, Michael R.; Tong, Liuchuan; Kim, Sang Bok; Eisenach, Louise; Valle, Alvaro W.; Hardee, David; Gordon, Roy G.; Aziz, Michael J.; Marshak, Michael P.
        Science (Washington, DC, United States) (2015), 349 (6255), 1529-1532CODEN: SCIEAS; ISSN:0036-8075. (American Association for the Advancement of Science)
        Storage of photovoltaic and wind electricity in batteries could solve the mismatch problem between the intermittent supply of these renewable resources and variable demand. Flow batteries permit more economical long-duration discharge than solid-electrode batteries by using liq. electrolytes stored outside of the battery. We report an alk. flow battery based on redox-active org. mols. that are composed entirely of Earth-abundant elements and are nontoxic, nonflammable, and safe for use in residential and com. environments. The battery operates efficiently with high power d. near room temp. These results demonstrate the stability and performance of redox-active org. mols. in alk. flow batteries, potentially enabling cost-effective stationary storage of renewable energy.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXhsFCrtbjN&md5=03e98c7de27aa2f1cfe9c71b6e9823bc
      12. 12
        Skyllas-Kazacos, M.; Chakrabarti, M. H.; Hajimolana, S. A.; Mjalli, F. S.; Saleem, M. Progress in Flow Battery Research and Development. J. Electrochem. Soc. 2011, 158, R55– R79,  DOI: 10.1149/1.3599565
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        12
        Progress in Flow Battery Research and Development
        Skyllas-Kazacos, M.; Chakrabarti, M. H.; Hajimolana, S. A.; Mjalli, F. S.; Saleem, M.
        Journal of the Electrochemical Society (2011), 158 (8), R55-R79CODEN: JESOAN; ISSN:0013-4651. (Electrochemical Society)
        A review of the various redox-flow battery systems and their hybrid alternatives. The past few decades showed a rapid and continuous exhaustion of the available energy resources which may lead to serious energy global crises. Researchers have been focusing on developing new and renewable energy resources to meet the increasing fuel demand and reduce greenhouse gas emissions. A surge of research effort is also being directed towards replacing fossil fuel based vehicles with hybrid and elec. alternatives. Energy storage is now seen as a crit. element in future smart grid and elec. vehicle applications. Electrochem. energy storage systems offer the best combination of efficiency, cost and flexibility, with redox flow battery systems currently leading the way in this aspect. Relevant published work is reported and critically discussed. A comprehensive study of the available technologies is conducted in terms of tech. aspects as well as economic and environmental consequences. Some of the flow battery limitations and tech. challenges are also discussed and a range of further research opportunities are presented. Of the flow battery technologies that have been studied, the all-V redox flow battery has received the most attention and showed most promise in various pre-com. to com. stationary applications to date, while new developments in hybrid redox fuel cells are promising to lead the way for future applications in mech. and elec. vehicles that can be re-fueled.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXotVygs70%253D&md5=88087f3aebb6f5a22bc47f5d656b2335
      13. 13
        Skyllas-Kazacos, M.; Kazacos, G.; Poon, G.; Verseema, H. Recent advances with UNSW vanadium-based redox flow batteries. Int. J. Energy Res. 2010, 34, 182– 189,  DOI: 10.1002/er.1658
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        13
        Recent advances with UNSW vanadium-based redox flow batteries
        Skyllas-Kazacos, Maria; Kazacos, George; Poon, Grace; Verseema, Hugh
        International Journal of Energy Research (2010), 34 (2), 182-189CODEN: IJERDN; ISSN:0363-907X. (John Wiley & Sons Ltd.)
        A review. The vanadium redox flow battery pioneered by Skyllas-Kazacos et al. at the University of New South Wales (UNSW) is currently considered as one of the few electrochem. energy storage systems suitable for use in the large-scale utility applications that are emerging in response to the increasing global implementation of renewable energy technologies for the mitigation of greenhouse gas emissions. While the original all-vanadium redox flow battery (G1 VRF) has already been successfully implemented in a wide range of stationary field trials in Japan, U.S.A., Austria, Italy and Australia, further cost redn. has been needed for its widespread market up-take. In this paper, up to 80% efficiency is reported for the latest 5-10 kW G1 VRF battery stack employing low-cost stack materials that are expected to achieve the necessary cost structure for the majority of stationary energy storage applications. While the G1 VRF battery has shown high efficiencies and excellent cycle life, however, its low energy d. has restricted its use in mobile applications. The new Generation 2 vanadium bromide redox battery (G2 V/Br) patented by UNSW in 2001 has been shown to potentially double the energy d. of the G1 VRF battery, allowing mobile applications to be considered. In this paper, the performance of the G2 V/Br is presented at a range of temps. and the use of complexing agents is shown to successfully bind any bromine produced during charging to prevent the formation of bromine vapors.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXjtVSrs7k%253D&md5=25981d30ab55a9d060b94b07463230a5
      14. 14
        Skyllas-Kazacos, M.; Kasherman, D.; Hong, D.R.; Kazacos, M. Characteristics and performance of 1 kW UNSW vanadium redox battery. J. Power Sources 1991, 35, 399– 404,  DOI: 10.1016/0378-7753(91)80058-6
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        14
        Characteristics and performance of 1 kW UNSW vanadium redox battery
        Skyllas-Kazacos, Maria; Kasherman, D.; Hong, D. R.; Kazacos, M.
        Journal of Power Sources (1991), 35 (4), 399-404CODEN: JPSODZ; ISSN:0378-7753.
        An energy efficiency of ≤90% was attained by a 1-kW prototype V redox battery. Solns. of 1.5-2 M V sulfate in H2SO4 were used in both half cells, and >85% of theor. capacity can be utilized at discharged currents of 30-120 A. Energy losses of 2-3% are expected due to pumping of electrolytes, so that an overall energy efficiency of 87-88% is achieved. The battery has completed >100 charge-discharge cycles and long-term testing is in progress.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK3MXls1ejsbk%253D&md5=1c562e8377679e8d72be5492683fedb2
      15. 15
        Moseley, P. T.; Garche, J. Electrochemical Energy Storage for Renewable Sources and Grid Balancing, 1st ed.; Elsevier: Amsterdam, 2014.
        Google Scholar
        There is no corresponding record for this reference.
      16. 16
        Soloveichik, G. L. Flow Batteries: Current Status and Trends. Chem. Rev. 2015, 115, 11533– 11558,  DOI: 10.1021/cr500720t
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        16
        Flow Batteries: Current Status and Trends
        Soloveichik, Grigorii L.
        Chemical Reviews (Washington, DC, United States) (2015), 115 (20), 11533-11558CODEN: CHREAY; ISSN:0009-2665. (American Chemical Society)
        A review. The projected life of redox-flow battery (RFB) systems is longer than that of conventional batteries, although it should be still verified in field tests. Combined with higher usable storage capacity of RFBs, it results in their lower levelized cost of electricity even when the capital cost is twice as much. RFBs are the most economical when the discharge time is >3 h (C-rate < 1/3) and the system cost decreases with the duration of an application. They have less manufacturability issues due to the uniformity of electrolytes and cells. Independence of power and energy in RFBs allows for using the same chem. in different applications, but fundamental and applied research is needed for industry acceptance and wide implementation of this technol. in energy-storage systems. The "ideal" RFB most probably will employ a single, high energy d. electrolyte based on inexpensive materials and an advanced electrode design and materials to maximize power d.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXhsFamsr7N&md5=aacb0e0559d024cc51c7e6d53db5d835
      17. 17
        Kreutzer, H.; Yarlagadda, V.; Van Nguyen, T. Performance Evaluation of a Regenerative Hydrogen-Bromine Fuel Cell. J. Electrochem. Soc. 2012, 159, F331– F337,  DOI: 10.1149/2.086207jes
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        17
        Performance evaluation of a regenerative hydrogen-bromine fuel cell
        Kreutzer, Haley; Yarlagadda, Venkata; Van Nguyen, Trung
        Journal of the Electrochemical Society (2012), 159 (7), F331-F337CODEN: JESOAN; ISSN:0013-4651. (Electrochemical Society)
        Intermittent renewable energy sources like wind and solar require energy storage to be fully exploited. The H2-Br2 flow battery has been identified as a great candidate for this application because of its high energy conversion efficiency and power d. capability. To evaluate the performance of this system a fuel cell with a membrane electrode assembly made of a Nafion 212 membrane and electrodes with 0.55 mg Pt/cm2 loading was tested at 22° under the H2-H2, H2-O2, H2-Br2 modes to compare the performance between these systems. The exchange c.d. of the Br-/Br2 reactions on platinum was found to be about a quarter of that of the hydrogen reactions on the same substrate (0.3 mA/cm2 Pt vs. 1.2 mA/cm2 Pt). Peak power d. during discharge was 0.30 W/cm2 at a voltage efficiency of 70% for the H2-Br2 mode vs. 0.17 W/cm2 at 40% for the H2-O2 mode under similar conditions. The performance of the H2-Br2 fuel cell is detd. mainly by the ohmic and mass transport resistances in the cell, which could be improved by using higher reactant concns., higher operating temps., more conductive membranes, and electrode and cell designs that enhance transport.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38Xht12msbfK&md5=d4e02bac49e6f88d6708cc397cc4b8a3
      18. 18
        Braff, W. A.; Bazant, M. Z.; Buie, C. R. Membrane-less hydrogen bromine flow battery. Nat. Commun. 2013, 4, 2346,  DOI: 10.1038/ncomms3346
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        18
        Membrane-less hydrogen bromine flow battery
        Braff William A; Bazant Martin Z; Buie Cullen R
        Nature communications (2013), 4 (), 2346 ISSN:.
        In order for the widely discussed benefits of flow batteries for electrochemical energy storage to be applied at large scale, the cost of the electrochemical stack must come down substantially. One promising avenue for reducing stack cost is to increase the system power density while maintaining efficiency, enabling smaller stacks. Here we report on a membrane-less hydrogen bromine laminar flow battery as a potential high-power density solution. The membrane-less design enables power densities of 0.795 W cm(-2) at room temperature and atmospheric pressure, with a round-trip voltage efficiency of 92% at 25% of peak power. Theoretical solutions are also presented to guide the design of future laminar flow batteries. The high-power density achieved by the hydrogen bromine laminar flow battery, along with the potential for rechargeable operation, will translate into smaller, inexpensive systems that could revolutionize the fields of large-scale energy storage and portable power systems.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BC3sbgtVWitA%253D%253D&md5=bc4c93fa481aab2ab8bbc5f11b4828d7

        Andrews, J.; Seif Mohammadi, S. Towards a ‘proton flow battery: Investigation of a reversible PEM fuel cell with integrated metal-hydride hydrogen storage. Int. J. Hydrogen Energy 2014, 39, 1740– 1751,  DOI: 10.1016/j.ijhydene.2013.11.010
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        19
        Towards a 'proton flow battery': Investigation of a reversible PEM fuel cell with integrated metal-hydride hydrogen storage
        Andrews, John; Seif Mohammadi, Saeed
        International Journal of Hydrogen Energy (2014), 39 (4), 1740-1751CODEN: IJHEDX; ISSN:0360-3199. (Elsevier Ltd.)
        An innovative concept for integrating a metal hydride storage electrode into a reversible p exchange membrane (PEM) fuel cell is described and studied exptl. This new concept has the potential to increase roundtrip efficiency compared to the conventional H-based elec. energy storage system by eliminating the intermediate steps of H gas prodn., storage, and recovery. As only an inflow of H2O is needed in the charge mode, and air in discharge mode, the system is called a p flow battery. A H storage electrode was fabricated from a novel composite metal hydride-nafion material, and found to have acceptably high p and electron conductivities. Its H storage capacity is 0.6% of H, although the amt. of H recovered to run the device in fuel cell mode was much lower. These results provide initial confirmatory evidence that the p flow battery concept is tech. feasible, though addnl. research is still required to enhance both storage capacity and reversibility.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXhvFKgtLfL&md5=225f7eb6140f006b4a32e0d05022283a

        Petek, T. J.; Hoyt, N. C.; Savinell, R. F.; Wainright, J. S. Slurry electrodes for iron plating in an all-iron flow battery. J. Power Sources 2015, 294, 620– 626,  DOI: 10.1016/j.jpowsour.2015.06.050
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        21
        Slurry electrodes for iron plating in an all-iron flow battery
        Petek, Tyler J.; Hoyt, Nathaniel C.; Savinell, Robert F.; Wainright, Jesse S.
        Journal of Power Sources (2015), 294 (), 620-626CODEN: JPSODZ; ISSN:0378-7753. (Elsevier B.V.)
        Slurry electrodes are studied to decouple the energy storage capacity from the power delivery capability in an all-iron flow battery. For the slurry electrode to perform effectively, the battery neg. reaction must occur on the slurry particles at reasonably high current densities. Math. modeling is used to study the current distribution in a slurry electrode as a function of the slurry specific area and elec. cond. to achieve >95% plating in the slurry electrode (not on the flat plate) at > 200 mA/cm2. From the math. modeling, MWCNTs are selected to demonstrate slurry electrode performance. The exptl. performance of all-iron batteries charged using the MWCNT slurry electrodes is found to improve while increasing the battery state-of-charge. Two possible mechanisms contributing to this effect are an increase in electronic cond. of the slurry and an increase in plating kinetics. After cycling the battery, <5% of the total battery charge has plated onto the current collector.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXhtVWjsrfP&md5=1fe5180c5d24d389cc91bbe7e13e41ab

        Tucker, M. C.; Phillips, A.; Weber, A. Z. All-Iron Redox Flow Battery Tailored for Off-Grid Portable Applications. ChemSusChem 2015, 8, 3996– 4004,  DOI: 10.1002/cssc.201500845
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        22
        All-Iron Redox Flow Battery Tailored for Off-Grid Portable Applications
        Tucker, Michael C.; Phillips, Adam; Weber, Adam Z.
        ChemSusChem (2015), 8 (23), 3996-4004CODEN: CHEMIZ; ISSN:1864-5631. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        An all-iron redox flow battery is proposed and developed for end users without access to an electricity grid. The concept is a low-cost battery which the user assembles, discharges, and then disposes of the active materials. The design goals are: (1) minimize upfront cost, (2) maximize discharge energy, and (3) utilize non-toxic and environmentally benign materials. These are different goals than typically considered for electrochem. battery technol., which provides the opportunity for a novel soln. The selected materials are: low-carbon-steel neg. electrode, paper separator, porous-carbon-paper pos. electrode, and electrolyte soln. contg. 0.5 M Fe2(SO4)3 active material and 1.2 M NaCl supporting electrolyte. With these materials, an av. power d. around 20 mW cm-2 and a max. energy d. of 11.5 Wh L-1 are achieved. A simple cost model indicates the consumable materials cost US$6.45 per kWh-1, or only US$0.034 per mobile phone charge.

        Ambipolar zinc-polyiodide electrolyte for a high-energy density aqueous redox flow battery
        Li, Bin; Nie, Zimin; Vijayakumar, M.; Li, Guosheng; Liu, Jun; Sprenkle, Vincent; Wang, Wei
        Nature Communications (2015), 6 (), 6303CODEN: NCAOBW; ISSN:2041-1723. (Nature Publishing Group)
        Redox flow batteries are receiving wide attention for electrochem. energy storage due to their unique architecture and advantages, but progress has so far been limited by their low energy d. (∼25 Wh l-1). Here we report a high-energy d. aq. zinc-polyiodide flow battery. Using the highly sol. iodide/triiodide redox couple, a discharge energy d. of 167 Wh l-1 is demonstrated with a near-neutral 5.0 M ZnI2 electrolyte. NMR study and d. functional theory-based simulation along with flow test data indicate that the addn. of an alc. (ethanol) induces ligand formation between oxygen on the hydroxyl group and the zinc ions, which expands the stable electrolyte temp. window to from -20 to 50°C, while ameliorating the zinc dendrite. With the high-energy d. and its benign nature free from strong acids and corrosive components, zinc-polyiodide flow battery is a promising candidate for various energy storage applications.

        Weng, G.-M.; Li, Z.; Cong, G.; Zhou, Y.; Lu, Y.-C. Unlocking the capacity of iodide for high-energy-density zinc/polyiodide and lithium/polyiodide redox flow batteries. Energy Environ. Sci. 2017, 10, 735– 741,  DOI: 10.1039/C6EE03554J
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        25
        Unlocking the capacity of iodide for high-energy-density zinc/polyiodide and lithium/polyiodide redox flow batteries
        Weng, Guo-Ming; Li, Zhejun; Cong, Guangtao; Zhou, Yucun; Lu, Yi-Chun
        Energy & Environmental Science (2017), 10 (3), 735-741CODEN: EESNBY; ISSN:1754-5706. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        Highly sol. iodide/triiodide (I-/I3-) couples are one of the most promising redox-active species for high-energy-d. electrochem. energy storage applications. However, to ensure high reversibility, only two-thirds of the iodide capacity is accessed and one-third of the iodide ions act as a complexing agent to stabilize the iodine (I2), forming I3- (I2I-). Here, we exploit bromide ions (Br-) as a complexing agent to stabilize the iodine, forming iodine-bromide ions (I2Br-), which frees up iodide ions and increases the capacity. Applying this strategy, we demonstrate a novel zinc/iodine-bromide battery to achieve an energy d. of 101 W h Lposolyte+negolyte-1 (or 202 W h Lposolyte-1), which is the highest energy d. achieved for aq. flow batteries to date. This strategy can be further generalized to nonaq. iodide-based batteries (i.e. lithium/polyiodide battery), offering new opportunities to improve high-energy iodide-based energy storage technologies.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXjtlelt78%253D&md5=2359fa2eb00ad05f99ebbabd282ff8d8

        Gong, K.; Ma, X.; Conforti, K. M.; Kuttler, K. J.; Grunewald, J. B.; Yeager, K. L.; Bazant, M. Z.; Gu, S.; Yan, Y. A zinc-iron redox-flow battery under $100 per kWh of system capital cost. Energy Environ. Sci. 2015, 8, 2941– 2945,  DOI: 10.1039/C5EE02315G

        A zinc-iron redox-flow battery under $100 per kW h of system capital cost
        Gong, Ke; Ma, Xiaoya; Conforti, Kameron M.; Kuttler, Kevin J.; Grunewald, Jonathan B.; Yeager, Kelsey L.; Bazant, Martin Z.; Gu, Shuang; Yan, Yushan
        Energy & Environmental Science (2015), 8 (10), 2941-2945CODEN: EESNBY; ISSN:1754-5706. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        Redox flow batteries (RFBs) are one of the most promising scalable electricity-storage systems to address the intermittency issues of renewable energy sources such as wind and solar. The prerequisite for RFBs to be economically viable and widely employed is their low cost. Here we present a new zinc-iron (Zn-Fe) RFB based on double-membrane triple-electrolyte design that is estd. to have under $100 per kW h system capital cost. Such a low cost is achieved by a combination of inexpensive redox materials (i.e., zinc and iron) and high cell performance (e.g., 676 mW cm-2 power d.). Engineering of the cell structure is found to be crit. to enable the high power d. Our cost model shows that a Zn-Fe RFB demonstrates the lowest cost among some notable RFBs and could reach the 2023 cost target set by the U.S. Department of Energy ($150 per kW h).

        Characterization of a zinc-cerium flow battery
        Leung, P. K.; Ponce-de-Leon, C.; Low, C. T. J.; Shah, A. A.; Walsh, F. C.
        Journal of Power Sources (2011), 196 (11), 5174-5185CODEN: JPSODZ; ISSN:0378-7753. (Elsevier B.V.)
        The performance of a divided, parallel-plate Zn-Ce redox flow battery using methanesulfonic acid electrolytes was studied. Eight 2 and 3-dimensional electrodes were tested under both const. c.d. and const. cell voltage discharge. C felt and the 3-dimensional platinized Ti mesh electrodes exhibited superior performance over the 2-dimensional electrodes. The charge and discharge characteristics of the redox flow battery were studied under different operating conditions and Zn/Ce reactant, as well as methan-sulfonic acid concn. The cell performance improved at higher operating temps. and faster electrolyte flow rates. The no. of possible cycles increased at reduced states of charge. During 15 min charge/discharge per cycle expt., 57 cycles were obtained and the Zn reaction is the limiting process during long term operation.

        Material design and engineering of next-generation flow-battery technologies
        Park, Minjoon; Ryu, Jaechan; Wang, Wei; Cho, Jaephil
        Nature Reviews Materials (2017), 2 (1), 16080CODEN: NRMADL; ISSN:2058-8437. (Nature Publishing Group)
        Spatial sepn. of the electrolyte and electrode is the main characteristic of flow-battery technologies, which liberates them from the constraints of overall energy content and the energy/power ratio. The concept of a flowing electrolyte not only presents a cost-effective approach for large-scale energy storage, but has also recently been used to develop a wide range of new hybrid energy storage and conversion systems. The advent of flow-based lithium-ion, org. redox-active materials, metal-air cells and photoelectrochem. batteries promises new opportunities for advanced elec. energy-storage technologies. In this Review, we present a crit. overview of recent progress in conventional aq. redox-flow batteries and next-generation flow batteries, highlighting the latest innovative alternative materials. We outline their tech. feasibility for use in long-term and large-scale elec. energy-storage devices, as well as the limitations that need to be overcome, providing our view of promising future research directions in the field of redox-flow batteries.

        Hendriks, K. H.; Robinson, S. G.; Braten, M. N.; Sevov, C. S.; Helms, B. A.; Sigman, M. S.; Minteer, S. D.; Sanford, M. S. High-Performance Oligomeric Catholytes for Effective Macromolecular Separation in Nonaqueous Redox Flow Batteries. ACS Cent. Sci. 2018, 4, 189– 196,  DOI: 10.1021/acscentsci.7b00544
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        30
        High-Performance Oligomeric Catholytes for Effective Macromolecular Separation in Nonaqueous Redox Flow Batteries
        Hendriks, Koen H.; Robinson, Sophia G.; Braten, Miles N.; Sevov, Christo S.; Helms, Brett A.; Sigman, Matthew S.; Minteer, Shelley D.; Sanford, Melanie S.
        ACS Central Science (2018), 4 (2), 189-196CODEN: ACSCII; ISSN:2374-7951. (American Chemical Society)
        Nonaq. redox flow batteries (NRFBs) represent an attractive technol. for energy storage from intermittent renewable sources. In these batteries, elec. energy is stored in and extd. from electrolyte solns. of redox-active mols. (termed catholytes and anolytes) that are passed through an electrochem. flow cell. To avoid battery self-discharge, the anolyte and catholyte solns. must be sepd. by a membrane in the flow cell. This membrane prevents crossover of the redox active mols., while simultaneously allowing facile transport of charge-balancing ions. A key unmet challenge for the field is the design of redox-active mol./membrane pairs that enable effective electrolyte sepn. while maintaining optimal battery properties. Here, we demonstrate the development of oligomeric catholytes based on tris(dialkylamino)cyclopropenium (CP) salts that are specifically tailored for pairing with size-exclusion membranes composed of polymers of intrinsic microporosity (PIMs). Systematic studies were conducted to evaluate the impact of oligomer size/structure on properties that are crucial for flow battery performance, including cycling stability, charge capacity, soly., electron transfer kinetics, and crossover rates. These studies have led to the identification of a CP-derived tetramer in which these properties are all comparable, or significantly improved, relative to the monomeric counterpart. A proof-of-concept flow battery is demonstrated by pairing this tetrameric catholyte with a PIM membrane. After 6 days of cycling, no crossover is detected, demonstrating the promise of this approach. These studies provide a template for the future design of other redox-active oligomers for this application.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXos1aqtg%253D%253D&md5=684571680f39725bd3f23804b95f4358
      31. 31
        Doris, S. E.; Ward, A. L.; Baskin, A.; Frischmann, P. D.; Gavvalapalli, N.; Chénard, E.; Sevov, C. S.; Prendergast, D.; Moore, J. S.; Helms, B. A. Macromolecular Design Strategies for Preventing Active-Material Crossover in Non-Aqueous All-Organic Redox-Flow Batteries. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2017, 56, 1595– 1599,  DOI: 10.1002/anie.201610582
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        31
        Macromolecular Design Strategies for Preventing Active-Material Crossover in Non-Aqueous All-Organic Redox-Flow Batteries
        Doris, Sean E.; Ward, Ashleigh L.; Baskin, Artem; Frischmann, Peter D.; Gavvalapalli, Nagarjuna; Chenard, Etienne; Sevov, Christo S.; Prendergast, David; Moore, Jeffrey S.; Helms, Brett A.
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2017), 56 (6), 1595-1599CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        Intermittent energy sources, including solar and wind, require scalable, low-cost, multi-hour energy storage solns. in order to be effectively incorporated into the grid. All-Org. non-aq. redox-flow batteries offer a soln., but suffer from rapid capacity fade and low Coulombic efficiency due to the high permeability of redox-active species across the battery's membrane. Here we show that active-species crossover is arrested by scaling the membrane's pore size to mol. dimensions and in turn increasing the size of the active material above the membrane's pore-size exclusion limit. When oligomeric redox-active orgs. (RAOs) were paired with microporous polymer membranes, the rate of active-material crossover was reduced more than 9000-fold compared to traditional separators at minimal cost to ionic cond. This corresponds to an abs. rate of RAO crossover of less than 3 μmol cm-2 day-1 (for a 1.0 M concn. gradient), which exceeds performance targets recently set forth by the battery industry. This strategy was generalizable to both high and low-potential RAOs in a variety of non-aq. electrolytes, highlighting the versatility of macromol. design in implementing next-generation redox-flow batteries.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXlsFCjug%253D%253D&md5=5400264b004f3280d479cf18e4b2a919
      32. 32
        Goulet, M. A.; Tong, L.; Pollack, D. A.; Tabor, D. P.; Odom, S. A.; Aspuru-Guzik, A.; Kwan, E. E.; Gordon, R. G.; Aziz, M. J. Extending the Lifetime of Organic Flow Batteries via Redox State Management. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2019, 141, 8014– 8019,  DOI: 10.1021/jacs.8b13295
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        32
        Extending the Lifetime of Organic Flow Batteries via Redox State Management
        Goulet, Marc-Antoni; Tong, Liuchuan; Pollack, Daniel A.; Tabor, Daniel P.; Odom, Susan A.; Aspuru-Guzik, Alan; Kwan, Eugene E.; Gordon, Roy G.; Aziz, Michael J.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2019), 141 (20), 8014-8019CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        Redox flow batteries based on quinone-bearing aq. electrolytes have emerged as promising systems for energy storage from intermittent renewable sources. The lifetime of these batteries is limited by quinone stability. Here, we confirm that 2,6-dihydroxyanthrahydroquinone tends to form an anthrone intermediate that is vulnerable to subsequent irreversible dimerization. We demonstrate quant. that this decompn. pathway is responsible for the loss of battery capacity. Computational studies indicate that the driving force for anthrone formation is greater for anthraquinones with lower redn. potentials. We show that the decompn. can be substantially mitigated. We demonstrate that conditions minimizing anthrone formation and avoiding anthrone dimerization slow the capacity loss rate by over an order of magnitude. We anticipate that this mitigation strategy readily extends to other anthraquinone-based flow batteries and is thus an important step toward realizing renewable electricity storage through long-lived org. flow batteries.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1MXmslSgtbs%253D&md5=ff89b7e40629ea211cc596eb36d2c0e6
      33. 33
        Goulet, M.-A.; Aziz, M. J. Flow Battery Molecular Reactant Stability Determined by Symmetric Cell Cycling Methods. J. Electrochem. Soc. 2018, 165, A1466– A1477,  DOI: 10.1149/2.0891807jes
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        33
        Flow battery molecular reactant stability determined by symmetric cell cycling methods
        Goulet, Marc-Antoni; Aziz, Michael J.
        Journal of the Electrochemical Society (2018), 165 (7), A1466-A1477CODEN: JESOAN; ISSN:0013-4651. (Electrochemical Society)
        We present an unbalanced compositionally-sym. flow cell method for revealing and quantifying different mechanisms for capacity fade in redox flow batteries that are based on mol. energy storage. We utilize it, accompanied in some cases by a corresponding static-cell cycling method, to study capacity fade in cells comprising anthraquinone di-sulfonate, di-hydroxy anthraquinone, iron hexacyanide, Me viologen, and bis-trimethylammoniopropyl viologen. In all cases the cycling capacity decay is reasonably consistent with exponential in time and is independent of the no. of charge-discharge cycles imposed. By introducing pauses at various states of charge of the capacity-limiting side during cycling, we show that in some cases the temporal fade time const. is dependent on the state of charge. These observations suggest that mol. lifetime is dominated by chem. rather than electrochem. mechanisms. These mechanisms include irrecoverable chem. decompn. and recoverable interactions with cell materials. We conclude with recommendations for cell cycling protocols for evaluating stability of single electrolytes.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXhtVWltb3E&md5=b0cb15b2937c990426300b2a033e17ad
      34. 34
        Hollas, A.; Wei, X.; Murugesan, V.; Nie, Z.; Li, B.; Reed, D.; Liu, J.; Sprenkle, V.; Wang, W. A biomimetic high-capacity phenazine-based anolyte for aqueous organic redox flow batteries. Nat. Energy 2018, 3, 508– 514,  DOI: 10.1038/s41560-018-0167-3
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        34
        A biomimetic high-capacity phenazine-based anolyte for aqueous organic redox flow batteries
        Hollas, Aaron; Wei, Xiaoliang; Murugesan, Vijayakumar; Nie, Zimin; Li, Bin; Reed, David; Liu, Jun; Sprenkle, Vincent; Wang, Wei
        Nature Energy (2018), 3 (6), 508-514CODEN: NEANFD; ISSN:2058-7546. (Nature Research)
        Aq. sol. org. (ASO) redox-active materials have recently attracted significant attention as alternatives to traditional transition metal ions in redox flow batteries (RFB). However, reported reversible capacities of ASO are often substantially lower than their theor. values based on the reported max. solubilities. Here, we describe a phenazine-based ASO compd. with an exceptionally high reversible capacity that exceeds 90% of its theor. value. By strategically modifying the phenazine mol. structure, we demonstrate an increased soly. from near-zero with pristine phenazine to as much as 1.8 M while also shifting its redox potential by more than 400 mV. An RFB based on a phenazine deriv. (7,8-dihydroxyphenazine-2-sulfonic acid) at its near-satn. concn. exhibits an operating voltage of 1.4 V with a reversible anolyte capacity of 67 Ah l-1 and a capacity retention of 99.98% per cycle over 500 cycles.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXhtFemt7%252FF&md5=c48e4bc999d4fff4f44f26eb5a8b8526
      35. 35
        Sun, P.; Liu, Y.; Li, Y.; Shehzad, M. A.; Liu, Y.; Zuo, P.; Chen, Q.; Yang, Z.; Xu, T. 110th Anniversary: Unleashing the Full Potential of Quinones for High Performance Aqueous Organic Flow Battery. Ind. Eng. Chem. Res. 2019, 58, 3994– 3999,  DOI: 10.1021/acs.iecr.8b06391
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        35
        Unleashing the Full Potential of Quinones for High Performance Aqueous Organic Flow Battery
        Sun, Pan; Liu, Yahua; Li, Yuanyuan; Shehzad, Muhammad A.; Liu, Yazhi; Zuo, Peipei; Chen, Qianru; Yang, Zhengjin; Xu, Tongwen
        Industrial & Engineering Chemistry Research (2019), 58 (10), 3994-3999CODEN: IECRED; ISSN:0888-5885. (American Chemical Society)
        Aq. org. flow batteries (AOFBs) are promising energy storage solns. to counteract the intermittent and fluctuating nature of renewable energy. However, there are limited options of electrolyte chem. and many org. compds. are discarded because of their sluggish electrochem. kinetics, which would compromise the power capability of the AOFB. Here, exemplified by 2,5-dihydroxy-3,6-dimethyl-1,4-benzoquinone (DMBQ), two approaches are presented including engineering the mol. structure and utilizing an inexpensive catalyst to enhance the electrochem. kinetics of benzoquinones with the ultimate purpose of diminishing the electron transfer barrier thereby increasing the power capability of the AOFB. It is shown that, by exploiting these strategies, the electron transfer resistance could be reduced by 48.1, or 55.8%, resp., thereby leading to a 49.4 or 60.7% increase in the peak power d. of a flowing cell. The strategy could be extended to the full family of quinones and that it benefits further exploration of quinone-based high performance AOFBs.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1MXjslKltbo%253D&md5=054b90188f6e39ba1842d88b22e9a052
      36. 36
        Yang, Z. J.; Tong, L. C.; Tabor, D. P.; Beh, E. S.; Goulet, M. A.; De Porcellinis, D.; Aspuru-Guzik, A.; Gordon, R. G.; Aziz, M. J. Alkaline Benzoquinone Aqueous Flow Battery for Large-Scale Storage of Electrical Energy. Adv. Energy Mater. 2018, 8, 1702056,  DOI: 10.1002/aenm.201702056
        [Crossref], Google Scholar

      37. 37
        Darling, R.; Gallagher, K.; Xie, W.; Su, L.; Brushett, F. Transport Property Requirements for Flow Battery Separators. J. Electrochem. Soc. 2016, 163, A5029– A5040,  DOI: 10.1149/2.0051601jes
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        37
        Transport Property Requirements for Flow Battery Separators
        Darling, Robert; Gallagher, Kevin; Xie, Wei; Su, Liang; Brushett, Fikile
        Journal of the Electrochemical Society (2016), 163 (1), A5029-A5040CODEN: JESOAN; ISSN:0013-4651. (Electrochemical Society)
        Flow batteries are a promising technol. for storing and discharging megawatt hours of elec. energy on the time scale of hours. The separator between the pos. and neg. electrodes strongly affects tech. and economic performance. However, requirements for separators have not been reported in a general manner that enables quant. evaluation of new systems such as nonaq. flow batteries. This gap is addressed by deriving specifications for transport properties that are chem. agnostic and align with aggressive capital cost targets. Three key transport characteristics are identified: area-specific resistance RΩ, crossover c.d. ix, and the coupling between crossover and capacity loss Ψ. Suggested max. area-specific resistances are 0.29 and 2.3 Ω·cm2 for aq. and nonaq. batteries, resp. Allowable crossover rates are derived by considering the possible fates of active mols. that cross the separator and the coupling between Coulombic efficiency (CE) and capacity decline. The CE must exceed 99.992% when active species are unstable at the opposing electrode, while a CE of 97% can be tolerated when active mols. can be recovered from the opposing electrode. The contributions of diffusion, migration, and convection are discussed, quantified, and related to the phys. properties of the separator and the active materials.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXhvFyksr7P&md5=34caaa0eb0bc933390e33af20333592e
      38. 38
        Darling, R. M.; Weber, A. Z.; Tucker, M. C.; Perry, M. L. The Influence of Electric Field on Crossover in Redox-Flow Batteries. J. Electrochem. Soc. 2016, 163, A5014– A5022,  DOI: 10.1149/2.0031601jes
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        38
        The Influence of Electric Field on Crossover in Redox-Flow Batteries
        Darling, Robert M.; Weber, Adam Z.; Tucker, Michael C.; Perry, Mike L.
        Journal of the Electrochemical Society (2016), 163 (1), A5014-A5022CODEN: JESOAN; ISSN:0013-4651. (Electrochemical Society)
        Transport of active species through the ion-exchange membrane sepg. the electrodes in a redox-flow battery is an important source of inefficiency. Migration and electro-osmosis have significant impacts on the crossover of reactive anions, cations, and neutral species. In this paper, these phenomena are theor. and exptl. explored for com. cation-exchange membranes. The theor. anal. indicates that plotting the cumulative Coulombic mismatch between charge and discharge as a function of time can be used to assess crossover rates. The relative importance of migration and electro-osmosis over diffusion is quantified and shown to increase with increasing c.d. and membrane thickness because the contributions of migration and electro-osmosis to ionic flux are independent of membrane thickness and proportional to c.d., while diffusion is inversely proportional to membrane thickness and independent of c.d.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXhvFyksr7N&md5=8f9bbeed91f4c15ca3746dea514b9548
      39. 39
        Ashraf Gandomi, Y.; Aaron, D. S.; Mench, M. M. Coupled Membrane Transport Parameters for Ionic Species in All-Vanadium Redox Flow Batteries. Electrochim. Acta 2016, 218, 174– 190,  DOI: 10.1016/j.electacta.2016.09.087
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        39
        Coupled Membrane Transport Parameters for Ionic Species in All-Vanadium Redox Flow Batteries
        Ashraf Gandomi, Yasser; Aaron, D. S.; Mench, M. M.
        Electrochimica Acta (2016), 218 (), 174-190CODEN: ELCAAV; ISSN:0013-4686. (Elsevier Ltd.)
        One of the major sources of capacity loss in all-V redox flow batteries (VRFBs) is the undesired transport of active V species across the ion-exchange membrane, generically termed crossover. A novel system was designed and built to study the concn.- and electrostatic potential gradient-driven crossover for all V species through the membrane in real-time. For this study, a perfluorosulfonic acid membrane separator (Nafion 117) was used. The test system uses UV/visible (UV/visible) spectroscopy to differentiate V ion species and separates contributions to crossover stemming from concn. and electrostatic potential gradients. The rate of species transport through the ion-exchange membrane is state of charge dependent and, as a result, interaction coeffs. were deduced which can be used to better est. expected crossover over a range of operating conditions. The elec. field increases the neg.-to-pos. transport of V(II)/V(III) and suppress the pos.-to-neg. transport of V(IV)/V(V) during discharge, with an inverse trend during charging conditions. Elec.-field-induced transport coeffs. were deduced directly from exptl. data.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XhsFymur7J&md5=ea79182d6a62ba1492c9a5e8bed59f50

        Luo, Q.; Li, L.; Nie, Z.; Wang, W.; Wei, X.; Li, B.; Chen, B.; Yang, Z. In-situ investigation of vanadium ion transport in redox flow battery. J. Power Sources 2012, 218, 15– 20,  DOI: 10.1016/j.jpowsour.2012.06.066
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        40
        In-situ investigation of vanadium ion transport in redox flow battery
        Luo, Qingtao; Li, Liyu; Nie, Zimin; Wang, Wei; Wei, Xiaoliang; Li, Bin; Chen, Baowei; Yang, Zhenguo
        Journal of Power Sources (2012), 218 (), 15-20CODEN: JPSODZ; ISSN:0378-7753. (Elsevier B.V.)
        Flow batteries with vanadium and iron redox couples as the electroactive species are employed to investigate the transport behavior of vanadium ions in the presence of an elec. field. It is shown that the elec. field accelerated the pos.-to-neg. and reduced the neg.-to-pos. transport of vanadium ions in the charging process and affected the vanadium ion transport in the opposite way during discharge. In addn., a method is designed to differentiate the concn.-gradient-driven vanadium ion diffusion and elec.-field-driven vanadium ion migration. A simplified math. model is established to simulate the vanadium ion transport in real charge-discharge operation of the flow battery. The concn. gradient diffusion coeffs. and elec.-migration coeffs. of V2+, V3+, VO2+, and VO2+ across a Nafion® membrane are obtained by fitting the exptl. data.

        Materials and Systems for Organic Redox Flow Batteries: Status and Challenges
        Wei, Xiaoliang; Pan, Wenxiao; Duan, Wentao; Hollas, Aaron; Yang, Zheng; Li, Bin; Nie, Zimin; Liu, Jun; Reed, David; Wang, Wei; Sprenkle, Vincent
        ACS Energy Letters (2017), 2 (9), 2187-2204CODEN: AELCCP; ISSN:2380-8195. (American Chemical Society)
        Redox flow batteries (RFBs) are propitious stationary energy storage technologies with exceptional scalability and flexibility to improve the stability, efficiency, and sustainability of our power grid. The redox-active materials are the key component for RFBs with which to achieve high energy d. and good cyclability. Traditional inorg.-based materials encounter crit. tech. and economic limitations such as low soly., inferior electrochem. activity, and high cost. Redox-active org. materials (ROMs) are promising alternative "green" candidates to push the boundaries of energy storage because of the significant advantages of mol. diversity, structural tailorability, and natural abundance. Here, the recent development of a variety of ROMs and assocd. battery designs in both aq. and nonaq. electrolytes are reviewed. The crit. challenges and potential research opportunities for developing practically relevant org. flow batteries are discussed.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        Leung, P.; Shah, A. A.; Sanz, L.; Flox, C.; Morante, J. R.; Xu, Q.; Mohamed, M. R.; Ponce de León, C.; Walsh, F. C. Recent developments in organic redox flow batteries: A critical review. J. Power Sources 2017, 360, 243– 283,  DOI: 10.1016/j.jpowsour.2017.05.057
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        43
        Recent developments in organic redox flow batteries: A critical review
        Leung, P.; Shah, A. A.; Sanz, L.; Flox, C.; Morante, J. R.; Xu, Q.; Mohamed, M. R.; Ponce de Leon, C.; Walsh, F. C.
        Journal of Power Sources (2017), 360 (), 243-283CODEN: JPSODZ; ISSN:0378-7753. (Elsevier B.V.)
        A review is given. Redox flow batteries (RFBs) have emerged as prime candidates for energy storage on the medium and large scales, particularly at the grid scale. The demand for versatile energy storage continues to increase as more elec. energy is generated from intermittent renewable sources. A major barrier in the way of broad deployment and deep market penetration is the use of expensive metals as the active species in the electrolytes. The use of org. redox couples in aq. or non-aq. electrolytes is a promising approach to reducing the overall cost in long-term, since these materials can be low-cost and abundant. The performance of such redox couples can be tuned by modifying their chem. structure. In recent years, significant developments in org. redox flow batteries has taken place, with the introduction of new groups of highly sol. org. mols., capable of providing a cell voltage and charge capacity comparable to conventional metal-based systems. This paper summarizes the fundamental developments and characterization of org. redox flow batteries from both the chem. and materials perspectives. The latest advances, future challenges and opportunities for further development are discussed.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXpslWkurk%253D&md5=c6372d8657e4d3809a8c3f396fd6d415

        Leung, P.; Li, X.; Ponce de León, C.; Berlouis, L.; Low, C. T. J.; Walsh, F. C. Progress in redox flow batteries, remaining challenges and their applications in energy storage. RSC Adv. 2012, 2, 10125,  DOI: 10.1039/c2ra21342g
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        44
        Progress in redox flow batteries, remaining challenges and their applications in energy storage
        Leung, Puiki; Li, Xiaohong; Ponce de Leon, Carlos; Berlouis, Leonard; Low, C. T. John; Walsh, Frank C.
        RSC Advances (2012), 2 (27), 10125-10156CODEN: RSCACL; ISSN:2046-2069. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A review. Redox flow batteries, which have been developed over the last 40 years, are used to store energy on the medium to large scale, particularly in applications such as load leveling, power quality control and facilitating renewable energy deployment. Various electrode materials and cell chemistries have been proposed; some of the successful systems have been demonstrated on a large-scale in the range of 10 kW-10 MW. Enhanced performance is attributable to the improvements in electrodes, separator materials and an increasing awareness of cell design. This comprehensive review provides a summary of the overall development of redox flow battery technol., including proposed chemistries, cell components and recent applications. Remaining challenges and directions for further research are highlighted.

        Chen, R. Toward High-Voltage, Energy-Dense, and Durable Aqueous Organic Redox Flow Batteries: Role of the Supporting Electrolytes. ChemElectroChem 2019, 6, 603– 612,  DOI: 10.1002/celc.201801505

        Toward High-Voltage, Energy-Dense, and Durable Aqueous Organic Redox Flow Batteries: Role of the Supporting Electrolytes
        Chen, Ruiyong
        ChemElectroChem (2019), 6 (3), 603-612CODEN: CHEMRA; ISSN:2196-0216. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        Sustainable energy supply from renewable sources requires highly efficient and economically competitive energy-storage technologies. With flexible design, high energy-storage efficiency, and long-term cyclability, redox flow batteries are superior candidates for peak shaving and load leveling for smart grids in the energy generation, storage and distribution networks. With natural abundance, structural diversity and tunability, redox-active org. species as valuable alternatives to the traditional inorg.-based materials are promising to tackle the resource and performance limitations. To design aq. org. redox flow batteries toward energy-dense, high-rate performance and durability, in this Review, strategies to maximize the cell voltage, effective concn. of org. species, and operating c.d. are discussed. Besides the inherent nature of the org. mols., suitable solvents and supporting ions can affect their solvation behavior and promote their chem. stability.

        Aqueous organic redox flow batteries
        Singh, Vikram; Kim, Soeun; Kang, Jungtaek; Byon, Hye Ryung
        Nano Research (2019), 12 (9), 1988-2001CODEN: NRAEB5; ISSN:1998-0000. (Springer GmbH)
        A review. Redox flow batteries (RFBs) are promising candidates to establish a grid-scale energy storage system for intermittent energy sources. While the current technol. of vanadium RFBs has been widely exploited across the world, the rise in the price of vanadium and its limited volumetric energy d. have necessitated the development of new kinds of redox active mols. Org. mols. can be used as new and economical redox couples in RFBs to address these issues. In addn., the redox org. species also provide ample advantages to increase the voltage and soly., provide multiple nos. of electron transfer, and ensure electrochem./chem. stability by mol. engineering through simple synthetic methods. This review focuses on the recent developments in aq. org. RFBs, including the mol. design and the corresponding cycling performance as these org. redox mols. are employed as either the negolyte or posolyte. Various strategies for tuning the electrochem./chem. characteristics of org. mols. have improved their soly., redox potential, cycling stability, and crossover issue across a sepg. membrane. We also put forward new strategies using nanotechnol. and our perspective for the future development of this rapidly growing field. [Figure not available: see fulltext.].

        Status and Prospects of Organic Redox Flow Batteries toward Sustainable Energy Storage
        Luo, Jian; Hu, Bo; Hu, Maowei; Zhao, Yu; Liu, T. Leo
        ACS Energy Letters (2019), 4 (9), 2220-2240CODEN: AELCCP; ISSN:2380-8195. (American Chemical Society)
        A review. Redox flow batteries (RFBs) are regarded a promising technol. for large-scale electricity energy storage to realize efficient utilization of intermittent renewable energy. Redox -active materials are the most important components in the RFB system because their physicochem. and electrochem. properties directly det. their battery performance and energy storage cost. Designable, tunable, and potentially low-cost redox-active org. compds. are promising alternatives to traditional redox-active inorg. compds. for RFB applications. Herein, the representative designs of redox-active mols., recent development of org. RFBs (ORFBs), and advantages/disadvantages of different ORFB are reviewed. Esp. the relationship between redox-active mols.' physicochem. properties and their battery performance is discussed with an emphasis on the side reactions that cause fading of battery capacity. Finally, an outlook is provided on the development of high-performance ORFBs for practical energy storage applications.

        Er, S.; Suh, C.; Marshak, M. P.; Aspuru-Guzik, A. Computational Design of Molecules for an All-Quinone Redox Flow Battery. Chem. Sci. 2015, 6, 885– 893,  DOI: 10.1039/C4SC03030C

        Computational design of molecules for an all-quinone redox flow battery
        Er, Suleyman; Suh, Changwon; Marshak, Michael P.; Aspuru-Guzik, Alan
        Chemical Science (2015), 6 (2), 885-893CODEN: CSHCCN; ISSN:2041-6520. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        Inspired by the electron transfer properties of quinones in biol. systems, we recently showed that quinones are also very promising electroactive materials for stationary energy storage applications. Due to the practically infinite chem. space of org. mols., the discovery of addnl. quinones or other redox-active org. mols. for energy storage applications is an open field of inquiry. Here, we introduce a high-throughput computational screening approach that we applied to an accelerated study of a total of 1710 quinone (Q) and hydroquinone (QH2) (i.e., two-electron two-proton) redox couples. We identified the promising candidates for both the neg. and pos. sides of org.-based aq. flow batteries, thus enabling an all-quinone battery. To further aid the development of addnl. interesting electroactive small mols. we also provide emerging quant. structure-property relationships.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXitVSitrzF&md5=47e9269451f3d0a6dabac2d994d08ef1
      49. 49
        Huynh, M. T.; Anson, C. W.; Cavell, A. C.; Stahl, S. S.; Hammes-Schiffer, S. Quinone 1 e- and 2 e-/2 H+ Reduction Potentials: Identification and Analysis of Deviations from Systematic Scaling Relationships. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2016, 138, 15903– 15910,  DOI: 10.1021/jacs.6b05797
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        49
        Quinone 1 e- and 2 e-/2 H+ Reduction Potentials: Identification and Analysis of Deviations from Systematic Scaling Relationships
        Huynh, Mioy T.; Anson, Colin W.; Cavell, Andrew C.; Stahl, Shannon S.; Hammes-Schiffer, Sharon
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2016), 138 (49), 15903-15910CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        Quinones participate in diverse electron transfer and proton-coupled electron transfer processes in chem. and biol. To understand the relationship between these redox processes, an exptl. study was carried out to probe the 1 e- and 2 e-/ 2 H+ redn. potentials of a no. of common quinones. The results reveal a non-linear correlation between the 1 e- and 2 e-/ 2 H+ redn. potentials. This unexpected observation prompted a computational study of 134 different quinones, probing their 1 e- redn. potentials, pKa values, and 2 e-/ 2 H+ redn. potentials. The d. functional theory calcns. reveal an approx. linear correlation between these three properties and an effective Hammett const. assocd. with the quinone substituent(s). However, deviations from this linear scaling relationship are evident for quinones that feature intramol. hydrogen bonding, halogen substituents, charged substituents, and/or sterically bulky substituents. These results, particularly the different substituent effects on the 1 e- vs. 2 e-/ 2 H+ redn. potentials, have important implications for designing quinones with tailored redox properties.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XhvVCjsLvK&md5=0af37a2e89ae549017f8c64d6cc2ba20
      50. 50
        Kim, H.; Goodson, T.; Zimmerman, P. M. Achieving Accurate Reduction Potential Predictions for Anthraquinones in Water and Aprotic Solvents: Effects of Inter- and Intramolecular H-Bonding and Ion Pairing. J. Phys. Chem. C 2016, 120, 22235– 22247,  DOI: 10.1021/acs.jpcc.6b07558
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        50
        Achieving Accurate Reduction Potential Predictions for Anthraquinones in Water and Aprotic Solvents: Effects of Inter- and Intramolecular H-Bonding and Ion Pairing
        Kim, Hyungjun; Goodson, Theodore; Zimmerman, Paul M.
        Journal of Physical Chemistry C (2016), 120 (39), 22235-22247CODEN: JPCCCK; ISSN:1932-7447. (American Chemical Society)
        In this combined computational and exptl. study, specific chem. interactions affecting the prediction of 1-electron and two-electron redn. potentials for anthraquinone derivs. were studied. For 19 redox reactions in acidic aq. soln., where AQ is reduced to hydroanthraquinone, d. functional theory (DFT) with the polarizable continuum model (PCM) gives a mean abs. deviation (MAD) of 0.037 V for 16 species. DFT(PCM), however, highly overestimates three redox couples with a MAD of 0.194 V, which is almost 5 times that of the remaining 16. These three mols. have ether groups positioned for intramol. H bonding that are not balanced with the intermol. H-bonding of the solvent. This imbalanced description is cor. by quantum mechanics/mol. mechanics (QM/MM) simulations, which include explicit H2O mols. The best theor. estns. result in a good correlation with expts., V(Theory) = 0.903 V(Expt) + 0.007 with an R2 value of 0.835 and an MAD of 0.033 V. In addn. to the aq. test set, 221 anthraquinone redox couples in aprotic solvent were studied. Five anthraquinone derivs. spanning a range of redox potentials were selected from this library, and their redn. potentials were measured by cyclic voltammetry. DFT(PCM) calcns. predict the 1st redn. potential with high accuracy giving the linear relation, V(Theory) = 0.960 V(Expt) - 0.049 with an R2 value of 0.937 and an MAD of 0.051 V. This approach, however, significantly underestimates the 2nd redn. potential, with an MAD of 0.329 V. It is shown herein that treatment of explicit ion-pair interactions between the anthraquinone derivs. and the cation of the supporting electrolyte is required for the accurate prediction of the 2nd redn. potential. After the correction, V(Theory) = 1.045 V(Expt) - 0.088 with an R2 value 0.910 and an MAD value reduced by more than half to 0.145 V. Finally, mol. design principles are discussed that go beyond simple electron-donating and electron-withdrawing effects to lead to predictable and controllable redn. potentials.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        Lim, H.-D.; Lee, B.; Zheng, Y.; Hong, J.; Kim, J.; Gwon, H.; Ko, Y.; Lee, M.; Cho, K.; Kang, K. Rational design of redox mediators for advanced Li-O2 batteries. Nat. Energy 2016, 1, 16066,  DOI: 10.1038/nenergy.2016.66
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        51
        Rational design of redox mediators for advanced Li-O2 batteries
        Lim, Hee-Dae; Lee, Byungju; Zheng, Yongping; Hong, Jihyun; Kim, Jinsoo; Gwon, Hyeokjo; Ko, Youngmin; Lee, Minah; Cho, Kyeongjae; Kang, Kisuk
        Nature Energy (2016), 1 (6), 16066CODEN: NEANFD; ISSN:2058-7546. (Nature Publishing Group)
        The discovery of effective catalysts is an important step towards achieving Li-O2 batteries with long cycle life and high round-trip efficiency. Sol.-type catalysts or redox mediators (RMs) possess great advantages over conventional solid catalysts, generally exhibiting much higher efficiency. Here, we select a series of org. RM candidates as a model system to identify the key descriptor in detg. the catalytic activities and stabilities in Li-O2 cells. It is revealed that the level of ionization energies, readily available parameters from a database of the mols., can serve such a role when comparing with the formation energy of Li2O2 and the HOMO energy of the electrolyte. It is demonstrated that they are crit. in reducing the overpotential and improving the stability of Li-O2 cells, resp. Accordingly, we propose a general principle for designing feasible catalysts and report a RM, dimethylphenazine, with a remarkably low overpotential and high stability.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        55
        Preferential Solvation of an Asymmetric Redox Molecule
        Han, Kee Sung; Rajput, Nav Nidhi; Vijayakumar, M.; Wei, Xiaoliang; Wang, Wei; Hu, Jianzhi; Persson, Kristin A.; Mueller, Karl T.
        Journal of Physical Chemistry C (2016), 120 (49), 27834-27839CODEN: JPCCCK; ISSN:1932-7447. (American Chemical Society)
        The fundamental correlations between soly. and solvation structure for the electrolyte system comprising N-(ferrocenylmethyl)-N,N-dimethyl-N-ethylammonium bistrifluoromethylsulfonimide (Fc1N112-TFSI) dissolved in a ternary carbonate solvent mixt. is analyzed using combined NMR relaxation and computational methods. Probing the evolution of the solvent-solvent, ion-solvent and ion-ion interactions with an increase in solute concn. provides a mol. level understanding of the soly. limit of the Fc1N112-TFSI system. An increase in solute concn. leads to pronounced Fc1N112-TFSI contact-ion pair formation by diminishing solvent-solvent and ion-solvent type interactions. At the soly. limit, the pptn. of solute is initiated through agglomeration of contact-ion pairs due to overlapping solvation shells.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XhvVGqsbbN&md5=1aa4c84a7fa4187be7e211bd8dd1b741
