        Luo, J.; Hu, B.; Debruler, C.; Bi, Y.; Zhao, Y.; Yuan, B.; Hu, M.; Wu, W.; Liu, T. L. Unprecedented capacity and stability of ammonium ferrocyanide catholyte in pH neutral aqueous redox flow batteries. Joule 2019, 3, 149– 163,  DOI: 10.1016/j.joule.2018.10.010
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        56
        Unprecedented Capacity and Stability of Ammonium Ferrocyanide Catholyte in pH Neutral Aqueous Redox Flow Batteries
        Luo, Jian; Hu, Bo; Debruler, Camden; Bi, Yujing; Zhao, Yu; Yuan, Bing; Hu, Maowei; Wu, Wenda; Liu, T. Leo
        Joule (2019), 3 (1), 149-163CODEN: JOULBR; ISSN:2542-4351. (Cell Press)
        Aq. org./organometallic redox flow batteries (AORFBs) have gained increasing attention for large-scale storage of intermittent renewable energy (e.g., solar and wind) due to the advantages of decoupled energy and power, high current and power performance, safety features, and synthetic tunability of charge storage mols. Here, we report the synthesis and physicochem. properties of highly water-sol. (NH4)3[Fe(CN)6] and (NH4)4[Fe(CN)6] catholyte materials and their application in pH neutral AORFBs. A 1.5 M half-cell (NH4)3[Fe(CN)6]/(NH4)4[Fe(CN)6] redox flow battery confirmed the high capacity and stability of ammonium ferrocyanide catholyte at pH neutral conditions. Paired with 1,1'-bis(3-sulfonatopropyl)-4,4'-bipyridinium ((SPr)2V) anolyte, a 0.9 M sym. (NH4)4[Fe(CN)6]/(SPr)2V AORFB free of supporting electrolytes exhibited excellent cycling performance including nearly 100% capacity retention in 1,000 cycles (1,100 testing hours), 62.6% energy efficiency at 40 mA/cm2 operation c.d., and a power d. of 72.5 mW/cm2, representing the most stable AORFB reported so far.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1MXhsValtLY%253D&md5=e1af63c0836c06860dc7ed120f8e59ba
      57. 57
        Hamlin, T. A.; Swart, M.; Bickelhaupt, F. M. Nucleophilic Substitution (SN2): Dependence on Nucleophile, Leaving Group, Central Atom, Substituents, and Solvent. ChemPhysChem 2018, 19, 1315– 1330,  DOI: 10.1002/cphc.201701363
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        57
        Nucleophilic Substitution (SN2): Dependence on Nucleophile, Leaving Group, Central Atom, Substituents, and Solvent
        Hamlin, Trevor A.; Swart, Marcel; Bickelhaupt, F. Matthias
        ChemPhysChem (2018), 19 (11), 1315-1330CODEN: CPCHFT; ISSN:1439-4235. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        A review. The reaction potential energy surface (PES), and thus the mechanism of bimol. nucleophilic substitution (SN2), depends profoundly on the nature of the nucleophile and leaving group, but also on the central, electrophilic atom, its substituents, as well as on the medium in which the reaction takes place. Here, we provide an overview of recent studies and demonstrate how changes in any one of the aforementioned factors affect the SN2 mechanism. One of the most striking effects is the transition from a double-well to a single-well PES when the central atom is changed from a second-period (e. g. carbon) to a higher-period element (e.g, silicon, germanium). Variations in nucleophilicity, leaving group ability, and bulky substituents around a second-row element central atom can then be exploited to change the single-well PES back into a double-well. Reversely, these variations can also be used to produce a single-well PES for second-period elements, for example, a stable pentavalent carbon species.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXotVaksrw%253D&md5=a5113e43d1ffe0fcd1b9f5a9ff03ca98

      59. 59
        Tabor, D. P.; Gómez-Bombarelli, R.; Tong, L.; Gordon, R. G.; Aziz, M. J.; Aspuru-Guzik, A. Mapping the frontiers of quinone stability in aqueous media: implications for organic aqueous redox flow batteries. J. Mater. Chem. A 2019, 7, 12833– 12841,  DOI: 10.1039/C9TA03219C
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        59
        Mapping the frontiers of quinone stability in aqueous media: implications for organic aqueous redox flow batteries
        Tabor, Daniel P.; Gomez-Bombarelli, Rafael; Tong, Liuchuan; Gordon, Roy G.; Aziz, Michael J.; Aspuru-Guzik, Alan
        Journal of Materials Chemistry A: Materials for Energy and Sustainability (2019), 7 (20), 12833-12841CODEN: JMCAET; ISSN:2050-7496. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        Quinone-hydroquinone pairs have been proposed as biol.-inspired, low-cost redox couples for org. electrolytes for elec. energy storage, particularly in aq. redox flow batteries. In their oxidized form, quinones are electrophiles that can react with the nucleophilic water solvent resulting in loss of active electrolyte. Here we study two mechanisms of nucleophilic addn. of water, one reversible and one irreversible, that limit quinone performance in practical flow batteries. Using a combination of d. functional theory and semi-empirical calcns., we have quantified the source of the instability of quinones in water, and explored the relationships between chem. structure, electrochem. redn. potential, and decompn. or instability mechanisms. The importance of these mechanisms was further verified through exptl. characterization of a family of alizarin-derived quinones. Finally, ∼140 000 prospective quinone pairs (over 1 000 000 calcns. including decompn. products) were analyzed in a virtual screening using the learned design principles. Our conclusions suggest that numerous low redn. potential mols. are stable with respect to nucleophilic addn., but promising high redn. potential mols. are much rarer. This latter fact suggests the existence of a stability cliff for this family of quinone-based org. mols., which challenges the development of all-quinone aq. redox flow batteries.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1MXovVOntbs%253D&md5=f86206bf94fe0a0156593dd549370390

        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        60
        A metal-free organic-inorganic aqueous flow battery
        Huskinson, Brian; Marshak, Michael P.; Suh, Changwon; Er, Sueleyman; Gerhardt, Michael R.; Galvin, Cooper J.; Chen, Xudong; Aspuru-Guzik, Alan; Gordon, Roy G.; Aziz, Michael J.
        Nature (London, United Kingdom) (2014), 505 (7482), 195-198CODEN: NATUAS; ISSN:0028-0836. (Nature Publishing Group)
        A class of energy storage materials that exploits the favorable chem. and electrochem. properties of a family of mols. known as quinones is described. The metal-free flow battery based on the redox chem. of 9,10-anthraquinone-2,7-disulfonic acid (AQDS) is demonstrated. AQDS undergoes extremely rapid and reversible 2-electron 2-proton redn. on a glassy C electrode in H2SO4. An aq. flow battery with inexpensive C electrodes, combining the quinone/hydroquinone couple with the Br2/Br- redox couple, yields a peak galvanic power d. exceeding 0.6 W cm-2 at 1.3 A cm-2. Cycling of this quinone-bromide flow battery showed >99% storage capacity retention per cycle. The org. anthraquinone species can be synthesized from inexpensive commodity chems. This org. approach permits tuning of important properties such as the redn. potential and soly. by adding functional groups: for example, the addn. of 2 hydroxy groups to AQDS increases the open circuit potential of the cell by 11% and a pathway for further increases in cell voltage is described. The use of π-arom. redox-active org. mols. instead of redox-active metals represents a new and promising direction for realizing massive elec. energy storage at greatly reduced cost.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXltVeisg%253D%253D&md5=1b7dd54b61bf90746959bb51e671c7a5

        Murali, A.; Nirmalchandar, A.; Krishnamoorthy, S.; Hoober-Burkhardt, L.; Yang, B.; Soloveichik, G.; Prakash, G. K. S.; Narayanan, S. R. Understanding and mitigating capacity fade in aqueous organic redox flow batteries. J. Electrochem. Soc. 2018, 165, A1193,  DOI: 10.1149/2.0161807jes
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        61
        Understanding and mitigating capacity fade in aqueous organic redox flow batteries
        Murali, Advaith; Nirmalchandar, Archith; Krishnamoorthy, Sankarganesh; Hoober-Burkhardt, Lena; Yang, Bo; Soloveichik, Grigorii; Prakash, G. K. Surya; Narayanan, S. R.
        Journal of the Electrochemical Society (2018), 165 (7), A1193-A1203CODEN: JESOAN; ISSN:0013-4651. (Electrochemical Society)
        The promising attributes of 3,6-dihydroxy-2,4-dimethylbenzenesulfonic acid (DHDMBS) as a pos. side material for aq. org. redox flow batteries have been reported previously by our group. In the present study, we focus on understanding and mitigating the crossover of DHDMBS from the pos. side of the cell to the neg. side and the possible degrdn. pathways that could lead to capacity fade. We also uncover a slow process of "protodesulfonation" of DHDMBS that results in capacity fade during long-term cycling under strongly acidic conditions. We demonstrate the benefit of low-permeability membranes, mixed electrolytes in a sym. cell configuration, use of electrolyte solns. with reduced acidity, and operating protocols involving polarity switching that reduce the rate of capacity fade substantially. These insights were used towards demonstrating long-term cycling of a sym. cell with a capacity fade rate <0.02% per h. The understanding and methods presented here are aimed at advancing the development of Org. Redox Flow Batteries (ORBAT) as an inexpensive and sustainable soln. for large-scale elec. energy storage.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        Orita, A.; Verde, M. G.; Sakai, M.; Meng, Y. S. The impact of pH on side reactions for aqueous redox flow batteries based on nitroxyl radical compounds. J. Power Sources 2016, 321, 126– 134,  DOI: 10.1016/j.jpowsour.2016.04.136

        63
        The impact of pH on side reactions for aqueous redox flow batteries based on nitroxyl radical compounds
        Orita, A.; Verde, M. G.; Sakai, M.; Meng, Y. S.
        Journal of Power Sources (2016), 321 (), 126-134CODEN: JPSODZ; ISSN:0378-7753. (Elsevier B.V.)
        Electrochem. and UV-VIS measurements demonstrate that the pH value of a 4-hydroxy-2,2,6,6-tetramethyl-1-pipperidinyloxyl (TEMPOL) electrolyte significantly impacts its redox reversibility. The diffusion coeff. and kinetic rate const. of TEMPOL in neutral aq. soln. are detd. and shown to be comparable to those of vanadium ions used for industrially utilized redox flow batteries (RFBs). RFBs that incorporate a TEMPOL catholyte and Zn-based anolyte have an av. voltage of 1.46 V and an energy efficiency of 80.4% during the initial cycle, when subject to a const. current of 10 mA cm-2. It is demonstrated several factors that significantly affect the concn. and capacity retention of TEMPOL upon cycling; namely, pH and atm. gases dissolved in electrolyte. The known reactions of TEMPOL in aq. electrolyte are expanded and several concepts are proposed to improve its electrochem. performance in a RFB. Controlling these factors is the key to enable the successful implementation of this relatively inexpensive and environmentally friendly battery.

        64
        Unraveling pH dependent cycling stability of ferricyanide/ferrocyanide in redox flow batteries
        Luo, Jian; Sam, Alyssa; Hu, Bo; De Bruler, Camden; Wei, Xiaoliang; Wang, Wei; Liu, T. Leo
        Nano Energy (2017), 42 (), 215-221CODEN: NEANCA; ISSN:2211-2855. (Elsevier Ltd.)
        K3[Fe(CN)6] and K4[Fe(CN)6] have been frequently applied in redox flow batteries to achieve sustainable and economical renewable energy storage. However, fundamental knowledge of the redox couple of K3[Fe(CN)6] and K4[Fe(CN)6] regarding their flow battery performance is largely underdeveloped. Herein, we present a comprehensive study on the fundamental properties and electrochem. kinetics of K3[Fe(CN)6] and K4[Fe(CN)6] in aq. supporting electrolytes at different pH values. Particularly, the charge/discharge cycling stability of the redox couple was evaluated at different pH values using a half-cell flow battery configuration. The battery results unambiguously confirmed that the redox couple functions best at neutral or near neutral conditions. Dramatic capacity decay of the redox couple was obsd. in a strong alk. KOH electrolyte (pH =14), which is due to the chem. decompn. assocd. with the CN- ligand dissocn. The presented study not only advances an in-depth understanding of K3[Fe(CN)6] and K4[Fe(CN)6] regarding their flow battery applications but also highlights the challenge of acid-base side reactions of redox active mols. applied in aq. acidic/alk. redox flow batteries.

        Tabbì, G.; Cassino, C.; Cavigiolio, G.; Colangelo, D.; Ghiglia, A.; Viano, I.; Osella, D. Water Stability and Cytotoxic Activity Relationship of a Series of Ferrocenium Derivatives. ESR Insights on the Radical Production during the Degradation Process. J. Med. Chem. 2002, 45, 5786– 5796,  DOI: 10.1021/jm021003k
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        66
        Water Stability and Cytotoxic Activity Relationship of a Series of Ferrocenium Derivatives. ESR Insights on the Radical Production during the Degradation Process
        Tabbi, Giovanni; Cassino, Claudio; Cavigiolio, Giorgio; Colangelo, Donato; Ghiglia, Annalisa; Viano, Ilario; Osella, Domenico
        Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2002), 45 (26), 5786-5796CODEN: JMCMAR; ISSN:0022-2623. (American Chemical Society)
        The cytotoxicity of some ferrocenium salts and the lack of activity of the corresponding ferrocenes has been already demonstrated. The cytotoxic activity in different conditions of decamethylferrocenium tetrafluoroborate (DEMFc+) in comparison with four other ferrocenium derivs. on MCF-7 cell line is reported. The relative stability in aq. solns. with different buffering agents is investigated by means of UV-vis spectroscopy and correlated to the cytotoxic properties of the compds. DEMFc+, the most stable compd., shows the highest efficiency in inhibiting cell growth (IC50 35 μM, for 48 h treatment). Relaxation time measurements point out the involvement of water mols. in the degrdn. process. ESR results confirm the ability of ferrocenium cations to produce oxygen radical species as a consequence of their degrdn. in water. Oxygen-dependent formation of both hydroxyl and superoxide radicals is established by the spin-trapping technique. A direct evidence of the DEMFc+ radical prodn. into the viable cells is obtained by means of fluorescence-activated cell sorter (FACS) anal. that reveals a dose-dependent growth of 8-oxoguanine, the initial product of the guanine oxidn. This DNA oxidative stress justifies the cytotoxic effect of DEMFc+. Furthermore, the cytotoxic cooperative effect of bleomycin, an iron-dependent antitumor drug, and DEMFc+ has been tested. We have demonstrated the synergic effect between the two drugs, that is explained by the complementary oxidative damage inflicted to DNA as well as by the increasing of bleomycin activation by the iron(II/III) species available in the cell compartment from ferrocenium degrdn.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD38XovVCht7c%253D&md5=2bc356be69c82c5328271f80eae69b3f

        Thomas, J.-L.; Howarth, J.; Hanlon, K.; McGuirk, D. Ferrocenyl imidazolium salts as a new class of anion receptors with C-H&X- hydrogen bonding. Tetrahedron Lett. 2000, 41, 413– 416,  DOI: 10.1016/S0040-4039(99)02072-9
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        67
        Ferrocenyl imidazolium salts as a new class of anion receptors with C-H···X- hydrogen bonding
        Thomas, Jean-Luc; Howarth, Joshua; Hanlon, Keith; McGuirk, Damien
        Tetrahedron Letters (2000), 41 (3), 413-416CODEN: TELEAY; ISSN:0040-4039. (Elsevier Science Ltd.)
        Ferrocenyl imidazolium salts (1-R-3-ferrocenylmethylimidazolium hexafluorophosphate; R = Me, Et, Pr, Bu; and 1,3-bis(ferrocenylmethyl)imidazolium hexafluorophosphate) were synthesized as novel anion receptors. 1H NMR studies showed that these compds. bind Cl-, Br-, I-, NO3- and HSO4- anions strongly in CDCl3 through C-H···X- H bonding. Diels-Alder reaction between methacrolein and cyclopentadiene gives endo and exo products in yields of 30-95% and endo/exo selectivities of 75-95% when the ferrocenyl imidazolium salts are present; no reaction occurs in their absence. Preliminary results of electrochem. studies are also reported.

        Gasser, G.; Fischmann, A. J.; Forsyth, C. M.; Spiccia, L. Products of hydrolysis of (ferrocenylmethyl)trimethylammonium iodide: Synthesis of hydroxymethylferrocene and bis(ferrocenylmethyl) ether. J. Organomet. Chem. 2007, 692, 3835– 3840,  DOI: 10.1016/j.jorganchem.2007.05.020
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        68
        Products of hydrolysis of (ferrocenylmethyl)trimethylammonium iodide: Synthesis of hydroxymethylferrocene and bis(ferrocenylmethyl) ether
        Gasser, Gilles; Fischmann, Adam J.; Forsyth, Craig M.; Spiccia, Leone
        Journal of Organometallic Chemistry (2007), 692 (17), 3835-3840CODEN: JORCAI; ISSN:0022-328X. (Elsevier Ltd.)
        The attempted coupling of (ferrocenylmethyl)trimethylammonium iodide (1) with 1,4,7-(triformyl)-1,4,7,10-tetraazacyclododecane (2) in water led to the formation of the expected compd. 1-(ferrocenemethyl)-4,7,10-(triformyl)-1,4,7,10-tetraazacyclododecane (3). In addn., hydrolysis of the ferrocenyl precursor 1 led to the formation of two other known compds., hydroxymethylferrocene (4) and bis(ferrocenylmethyl) ether (5). An x-ray crystal structure detn. of 4 revealed the presence of H-bonding between the hydroxyl groups of one mol. of 4 and the oxygen atom of an adjacent mol. resulting in a left-handed helical chain of mols. lying along the b-axis direction. The O···O distances are significantly shorter than those found in previously reported structures of hydroxymethylferrocene derivs. indicative of moderate strength H-bonding interactions. In the structure of 5, the orientation of the ferrocenyl groups are staggered relative to a vector comprising the two carbons of the C-O-C linker.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXnslKks78%253D&md5=6ab79f592dcc6a14c81460fde76f3239

        Bird, C. L.; Kuhn, A. T. Electrochemistry of the viologens. Chem. Soc. Rev. 1981, 10, 49– 82,  DOI: 10.1039/cs9811000049
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        69
        Electrochemistry of the viologens
        Bird, C. L.; Kuhn, A. T.
        Chemical Society Reviews (1981), 10 (1), 49-82CODEN: CSRVBR; ISSN:0306-0012.
        Half-wave polarog. redn. potentials of 66 viologens are reported (detd. by B. G. White et al.). The electrochem. of the viologens is discussed fully.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaL3MXltFCnt7s%253D&md5=9827d3a4c72c6578b244b83f38ac4b8c
      70. 70
        Murugavel, K. Benzylic viologen dendrimers: a review of their synthesis, properties and applications. Polym. Chem. 2014, 5, 5873– 5884,  DOI: 10.1039/C4PY00718B
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        70
        Benzylic viologen dendrimers: a review of their synthesis, properties and applications
        Murugavel, Kathiresan
        Polymer Chemistry (2014), 5 (20), 5873-5884CODEN: PCOHC2; ISSN:1759-9962. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A review. Here, the synthesis of benzylic viologen dendrimers, their guest complexation, photophys. and biol. applications have been reviewed. Divergent and convergent approaches reported by Walder et al. and Balzani et al. for the synthesis of benzylic viologen dendrimers are also discussed. Electron sponge behavior and their use as electron storage devices are elaborated. In addn., CT (charge transfer) complexation with guest anionic dye mols. and their use as charge storing devices are discussed. It has been shown that these dendrimers sequentially complex org. anions guided through mol. recognition. Anions with matching symmetry showed sharp chem. shifts in 1H NMR titrn. studies. The existence of a potential gradient is explained for such a preferential complexation mechanism. Thus, the sequential complexation of org. anions inside these dendrimers as confirmed by 1H NMR titrn. studies are briefly discussed. Further, the biol. applications focusing on their antiviral, antibacterial and antifungal activities reported so far have been addressed.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXhtFGlsrbP&md5=6cb9597ea00d6c52d3a7381f9b3ed8c8

      72. 72
        Venturi, M.; Mulazzani, Q. G.; Hoffman, M. Z. Radiolytically-induced one-electron reduction of methyl viologen in aqueous solution. Radiat. Phys. Chem. 1984, 23, 229– 236,  DOI: 10.1016/0146-5724(84)90113-4
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        72
        Radiolytically-induced one-electron reduction of methyl viologen in aqueous solution. Stability of the radical cation in acidic and highly alkaline media
        Venturi, Margherita; Mulazzani, Quinto G.; Hoffman, Morton Z.
        Radiation Physics and Chemistry (1984), 23 (1-2), 229-36CODEN: RPCHDM; ISSN:0146-5724.
        Pulse and continuous radiolysis were used to investigate the stability of the reduced Me viologen radical cation (MV+) in acidic and highly alk. aq. soln. The reaction of the Me viologen dication (MV2+) with (CH3)2·COH and (CH3)2·CO- radicals generates MV+ rapidly (k = 2.9 ± 0.2 × 109 and 6.7 ± 0.3 × 109 M-1 s-1, resp.). The absorption spectrum of MV+ is the same at pH 1, natural pH, and pH 13, suggesting that MV+ is not involved in acid-base equil. in that pH range. Between pH 0 and 2, MV+ disappears via second-order kinetics with kobs an inverse function of [MV2+] and pH. The decay of MV+ occurs via H+-assisted disproportionation and yields ultimately a hydrogenated species with λmax 220, 255 nm (εmax 8.2 × 103, 4.1 × 103 M-1 cm-1, resp.). At pH 13, MV+ is infinitely stable in the absence of O2; further redn. of MV+ yields the moderately stable MV0 species with λmax 368 nm (εmax 3.6 × 104 M-1 cm-1) and a shoulder at 370 nm (ε 3.0 × 104 M-1 cm-1). Reaction of MV0 with O2 yields MV2+ quant. via two one-electron oxidn. steps. Acidification of MV0 in the absence of O2 yields the same air-insensitive hydrogenation product as is obtained from the disproportionation of MV+ in acidic soln. The relation of these observations to the use of MV2+ as an electron relay species in photochem. solar energy conversion schemes is examd.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaL2cXlvFGitg%253D%253D&md5=4105afe2e249b1e8937fa0356c1fff2a

Koziol and P. Hemmerich (1976)].

        Smith, S. B.; Bruice, T. C. Mechanisms of isoalloxazine (flavine) hydrolysis. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 1975, 97, 2875– 2881,  DOI: 10.1021/ja00843a043
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        76
        Mechanisms of isoalloxazine (flavine) hydrolysis
        Smith, Stephen B.; Bruice, Thomas C.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (1975), 97 (10), 2875-81CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863.
        The kinetics of hydrolyses (μ = 1.0, 30°) of I (R = 2,6-xylyl, Ph, Me; R1 = H, Me) was studied using uv spectroscopy. I (R = 2,6-xylyl, R1 = Me) (II) showed a D solvent isotope effect of 0.6 and a second-order dependence in [OH-]. I (R = Ph, R1 = Me) hydrolyzed by the same mechanism as II and the hydrolysis of I (R = Ph, R2 = H) was first-order in [OH-]. The kinetics of base hydrolysis of I (R = R1 = Me) were biphasic as the result of two reaction paths each composed of two reactions with different pH dependence.

        Surrey, A. R.; Nachod, F. C. Alkaline Hydrolysis of Riboflavin. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 1951, 73, 2336– 2338,  DOI: 10.1021/ja01149a128
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        77
        Alkaline hydrolysis of riboflavin
        Surrey, Alexander R.; Nachod, Frederick C.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (1951), 73 (), 2336-40CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863.
        Riboflavin hydrolyzes in alk. soln. to give urea and 1,2-dihydro-6,7-dimethyl-2-keto-1-D-ribityl-3-quinoxalinecarboxylic acid. The latter compd. exhibits a depressant action on cardiac and visceral muscles when injected intravenously into dogs. The kinetics of the alk. degradation of riboflavin was followed spectrophotometrically in 0.25 N NaOH at 25° by using the max. at wave length = 445 mμ. The reaction was shown to be of first order with a rate of k25 = 1.62 × 10-2hr.-1.

        Hydrolysis products of flavins (isoalloxazines)
        Harayama, Takashi; Tezuka, Yasuhiro; Taga, Tooru; Yoneda, Fumio

        Hydrolysis of the flavins I (R = Ph, Me, Et, PhCH2, 2,6-Me2C6H3) with Triton B gave the 4a-spirohydantoins II as the major products, indicating preferential nucleophilic attack by OH at the 10a-position. The crystal structure of II (R = Ph)·(CD3)2SO was detd. A compd. previously obtained in the hydrolysis of I (R = CH2Ph) has been identified as the purinedione III.

        Lin, K.; Gómez-Bombarelli, R.; Beh, E. S.; Tong, L.; Chen, Q.; Valle, A.; Aspuru-Guzik, A.; Aziz, M. J.; Gordon, R. G. A redox-flow battery with an alloxazine-based organic electrolyte. Nat. Energy 2016, 1, 16102,  DOI: 10.1038/nenergy.2016.102
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        79
        A redox-flow battery with an alloxazine-based organic electrolyte
        Lin, Kaixiang; Gomez-Bombarelli, Rafael; Beh, Eugene S.; Tong, Liuchuan; Chen, Qing; Valle, Alvaro; Aspuru-Guzik, Alan; Aziz, Michael J.; Gordon, Roy G.
        Nature Energy (2016), 1 (9), 16102CODEN: NEANFD; ISSN:2058-7546. (Nature Publishing Group)
        Redox-flow batteries (RFBs) can store large amts. of elec. energy from variable sources, such as solar and wind. Recently, redox-active org. mols. in aq. RFBs have drawn substantial attention due to their rapid kinetics and low membrane crossover rates. Drawing inspiration from nature, here we report a high-performance aq. RFB utilizing an org. redox compd., alloxazine, which is a tautomer of the isoalloxazine backbone of vitamin B2. It can be synthesized in high yield at room temp. by single-step coupling of inexpensive o-phenylenediamine derivs. and alloxan. The highly alk.-sol. alloxazine 7/8-carboxylic acid produces a RFB exhibiting open-circuit voltage approaching 1.2 V and current efficiency and capacity retention exceeding 99.7% and 99.98% per cycle, resp. Theor. studies indicate that structural modification of alloxazine with electron-donating groups should allow further increases in battery voltage. As an aza-arom. mol. that undergoes reversible redox cycling in aq. electrolyte, alloxazine represents a class of radical-free redox-active orgs. for use in large-scale energy storage.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXhtVersrY%253D&md5=1bdb2e213c96396bad489b2404fbc367

        81
        1,1',8,8'-Tetramethoxy-10,10'-bianthrone
        Shi, Zheng Wei; Li, Yi Zhi; Li, Ying; Lu, Guo Yuan; Liu, Shan Hui
        Acta Crystallographica, Section E: Structure Reports Online (2004), 60 (12), o2275-o2277CODEN: ACSEBH; ISSN:1600-5368. (International Union of Crystallography)
        The title compd., 1,1',8,8'-tetramethoxy-9,9'-bianthracene-10,10'(9H,9'H)-dione, C32H26O6, was obtained by the redn. of 1,8-dimethoxyanthraquinone with Na borohydride and HO2CCF3. Crystallog. data are given. In the anthrone dimers, the methoxy and carbonyl groups are attached to opposite sides of the anthracene rings. In the solid state, the mol. has a crystallog. imposed center of symmetry located at the mid-point of the C-C bond linking the two anthracene systems.

      82. 82
        Jin, S.; Jing, Y.; Kwabi, D. G.; Ji, Y.; Tong, L.; De Porcellinis, D.; Goulet, M.-A.; Pollack, D. A.; Gordon, R. G.; Aziz, M. J. A Water-Miscible Quinone Flow Battery with High Volumetric Capacity and Energy Density. ACS Energy Lett. 2019, 4, 1342– 1348,  DOI: 10.1021/acsenergylett.9b00739
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        82
        A Water-Miscible Quinone Flow Battery with High Volumetric Capacity and Energy Density
        Jin, Shijian; Jing, Yan; Kwabi, David G.; Ji, Yunlong; Tong, Liuchuan; De Porcellinis, Diana; Goulet, Marc-Antoni; Pollack, Daniel A.; Gordon, Roy G.; Aziz, Michael J.
        ACS Energy Letters (2019), 4 (6), 1342-1348CODEN: AELCCP; ISSN:2380-8195. (American Chemical Society)
        A water-miscible anthraquinone with polyethylene glycol (PEG)-based solubilizing groups is introduced as the redox-active mol. in a neg. electrolyte (negolyte) for aq. redox flow batteries, exhibiting the highest volumetric capacity among aq. org. negolytes. A series of PEG-substituted anthraquinones (PEGAQs) are synthesized and screened and carefully studied one of its isomers, 1,8-bis(2-(2-(2-hydroxyethoxy)ethoxy)ethoxy)anthracene-9,10-dione (AQ-1,8-3E-OH), which has high electrochem. reversibility and is completely miscible in water of any pH. A negolyte contg. 1.5 M AQ-1,8-3E-OH, when paired with a ferrocyanide-based pos. electrolyte across an inexpensive, nonfluorinated permselective polymer membrane at pH 7, exhibits an open-circuit potential of 1.0 V, a volumetric capacity of 80.4 Ah/L, and an energy d. of 25.2 Wh/L.

        Thomson, R. H. 352. The structure of β-hydrojuglone and related compounds. Keto-;enols of the naphthalene series. J. Chem. Soc. 1950, 0, 1737– 1742,  DOI: 10.1039/JR9500001737
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        86
        Structure of β-hydrojuglone and related compounds. Keto-enols of the naphthalene series
        Thomson, R. H.
        Journal of the Chemical Society (1950), (), 1737-42CODEN: JCSOA9; ISSN:0368-1769.
        Juglone (5,1,4-HOC10H5O2) (1 g.) in 250 cc. 12% HCl contg. 5 g. SnCl2, refluxed 1 h., gives 0.65 g. β-hydroxyjuglone (5-hydroxy-1,4-diketo-1,2,3,4-tetrahydronaphthalene) (I), light yellow needles or plates from hexane or pale yellow leaflets from EtOH, m. 96-7° [mono(p-nitrophenylhydrazone), yellow, m. 270°]. α-Hydrojuglone (II) (0.5 g.) in 50 cc. 4% HCl contg. 2.5 g. SnCl2, refluxed 30 min., gives 95 mg. I. Fusion of II gives 67% I. This behavior of II argues against the natural occurrence of I as claimed by Mylius [Ber. 17, 2441(1884)]. 1,4-C10H6(OH)2 (III), fused by the method of Olay (C.A. 30, 2190.4), gives 55% unchanged III and 10.5% 1,4-diketo-1,2,3,4-tetrahydronaphthalene (IV), m. 98° [mono(p-nitrophenylhydrazone), orange-red, m. 255° (decompn.); bis(p-nitrophenylhydrazone), rust-red, m. 284° (decompn.)]. 2-Me deriv. (V) of IV, m. 66°, 11% [mono(p-nitrophenylhydrazone), rust-red, m. 242° (decompn.); bis(p-nitrophenylhydrazone), orange, m. 295° (decompn.)]. I, IV, or V do not react with Ac2O at room temp. (24 h.) or at 95° (2 h.); with a trace of concd. H2SO4, I gives an acetate, m. 114°, and some 1,4,5-C10H5(OH)3. III forms a bis(phenylurethane), m. 220°; the 2-Me deriv. m. 238°; 1,4,5-trihydroxynaphthalene tris(phenylurethane), m. 298°. IV (160 mg.) and 150 mg. p-ONC6H4NMe2 (VI) in 3 cc. MeOH, refluxed 30 min., give 250 mg. 2-(p-dimethylaminoanilino)-1,4-naphthoquinone (VII), purple-brown, m. 203° (decompn.); this results also from III and VI or from 1,4-C10H6O2 and p-H2NC6H4NMe2 (VIII); VII gives a red soln. in concd. H2SO4 and a royal-blue color in EtOH-NaOH; hydrolysis with 50% H2SO4 gives 2,1,4-HOC10H5O2. The initial reaction is the oxidn. of the enolic diketone to 1,4-C10H6O2 and redn. of VI to VIII. With V, the reaction does not proceed beyond the oxidn. stage. The proposed structure of I, for which pos. chem. evidence has not been obtained, is supported by the IR and UV absorption spectra. The IR spectra show no HO band near 3400 cm.-1, eliminating the enolic structures suggested by Olay. The diketo compds. exhibit few ketonic properties and under most conditions they enolize readily and yield only C10H8 derivs. Thus they do not have promising synthetic applications.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaG3MXmtFGh&md5=7c16c63917d039b0d17c8fbe9873237c

      88. 88
        Chen, Q.; Eisenach, L.; Aziz, M. J. Cycling Analysis of a Quinone-Bromide Redox Flow Battery. J. Electrochem. Soc. 2016, 163, A5057– A5063,  DOI: 10.1149/2.0081601jes
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        88
        Cycling Analysis of a Quinone-Bromide Redox Flow Battery
        Chen, Qing; Eisenach, Louise; Aziz, Michael J.
        Journal of the Electrochemical Society (2016), 163 (1), A5057-A5063CODEN: JESOAN; ISSN:0013-4651. (Electrochemical Society)
        The authors report the dependence upon c.d. of voltage polarization; charge capacity; and current, voltage, and energy efficiency for a flow battery comprising 2,7-anthraquinone disulfonic acid and HBr as redox-active species in the electrolytes. The authors develop relations predicting several of these figures of merit from the polarization curves. The decrease in capacity with increasing c.d. is a direct consequence of the interplay of the polarization curves and the voltage limits imposed during cycling. The linearity of the polarization curves results in an inverse linear relation between instantaneous voltage efficiency and c.d. The av. voltage efficiency over a complete cycle is shown to follow this same relation when the open-circuit voltage and polarization resistance are evaluated at 50% state of charge. Current efficiency loss mechanisms are classified according to whether they lead directly to cycle capacity loss. The current efficiency increases with c.d. due to const.-rate loss mechanisms at a rate of 1.08 mA/cm2, which is consistent with the rate of Br crossover. Quinone crossover is negligible at 140 pA/cm2. The effective differential capacity retention rate is 99.90% per cycle over 40 cycles. Mechanistic interpretations for these results are offered and interrelationships derived.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXhvFyksr7L&md5=de019c824898c7decbc2b9ffe5b8ffe4
      89. 89
        Chen, Q.; Gerhardt, M. R.; Aziz, M. J. Dissection of the voltage losses of an acidic quinone redox flow battery. J. Electrochem. Soc. 2017, 164, A1126– A1132,  DOI: 10.1149/2.0721706jes
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        89
        Dissection of the Voltage Losses of an Acidic Quinone Redox Flow Battery
        Chen, Qing; Gerhardt, Michael R.; Aziz, Michael J.
        Journal of the Electrochemical Society (2017), 164 (6), A1126-A1132CODEN: JESOAN; ISSN:0013-4651. (Electrochemical Society)
        The polarization characteristics are measured of a quinone-bromide redox flow battery with interdigitated flow fields, using electrochem. impedance spectroscopy and voltammetry of a full cell and of a half cell against a ref. electrode. The linear polarization behavior is found at 50% state of charge all the way to the short-circuit c.d. of 2.5 A/cm2. The polarization area-specific resistance (ASR) of each electrode, the membrane ASR to ionic current, and the electronic contact ASR are uniquely identified. The voltage probes are used to deduce the electronic c.d. through each sheet of carbon paper in the quinone-bearing electrode. By interpreting the results using the Newman 1-D porous electrode model, the volumetric exchange c.d. is deduced of the porous electrode. The power dissipation is uniquely evaluated and a correspondence is identified to the contributions to the electrode ASR from the faradaic, electronic, and ionic transport processes. It was found that, within the electrode, more power is dissipated in the faradaic process than in the electronic and ionic conduction processes combined, despite the obsd. linear polarization behavior. The sensitivity is examd. of the ASR to the values of the model parameters. The greatest performance improvement is anticipated from increasing the volumetric exchange c.d.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXntlSktbo%253D&md5=0c797ddd9e1e046772121f9307520176
      90. 90
        Beh, E. S.; De Porcellinis, D.; Gracia, R. L.; Xia, K. T.; Gordon, R. G.; Aziz, M. J. A neutral pH aqueous organic-organometallic redox flow battery with extremely high capacity retention. ACS Energy Lett. 2017, 2, 639– 644,  DOI: 10.1021/acsenergylett.7b00019
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        90
        A Neutral pH Aqueous Organic-Organometallic Redox Flow Battery with Extremely High Capacity Retention
        Beh, Eugene S.; De Porcellinis, Diana; Gracia, Rebecca L.; Xia, Kay T.; Gordon, Roy G.; Aziz, Michael J.
        ACS Energy Letters (2017), 2 (3), 639-644CODEN: AELCCP; ISSN:2380-8195. (American Chemical Society)
        We demonstrate an aq. org. and organometallic redox flow battery utilizing reactants composed of only earth-abundant elements and operating at neutral pH. The pos. electrolyte contains bis((3-trimethylammonio)propyl)ferrocene dichloride, and the neg. electrolyte contains bis(3-trimethylammonio)propyl viologen tetrachloride; these are sepd. by an anion-conducting membrane passing chloride ions. Bis(trimethylammoniopropyl) functionalization leads to ∼2 M soly. for both reactants, suppresses higher-order chem. decompn. pathways, and reduces reactant crossover rates through the membrane. Unprecedented cycling stability was achieved with capacity retention of 99.9943%/cycle and 99.90%/day at a 1.3 M reactant concn., increasing to 99.9989%/cycle and 99.967%/day at 0.75-1.00 M; these represent the highest capacity retention rates reported to date vs. time and vs. cycle no. We discuss opportunities for future performance improvement, including chem. modification of a ferrocene center and reducing the membrane resistance without unacceptable increases in reactant crossover. This approach may provide the decadal lifetimes that enable org.-organometallic redox flow batteries to be cost-effective for grid-scale electricity storage, thereby enabling massive penetration of intermittent renewable electricity.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXit12msrY%253D&md5=0b27106e1380cef821781323bd6cbeb7

        Xu, Y.; Wen, Y.; Cheng, J.; Cao, G.; Yang, Y. Study on a single flow acid Cd-chloranil battery. Electrochem. Commun. 2009, 11, 1422– 1424,  DOI: 10.1016/j.elecom.2009.05.021
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        92
        Study on a single flow acid Cd-chloranil battery
        Xu, Yan; Wen, Yuehua; Cheng, Jie; Cao, Gaoping; Yang, Yusheng
        Electrochemistry Communications (2009), 11 (7), 1422-1424CODEN: ECCMF9; ISSN:1388-2481. (Elsevier B.V.)
        This paper describes a novel redox flow battery-single flow acid Cd-chloranil battery. The electrolyte of this battery for both neg. electrode and pos. electrode is the aq. intermixt. of H2SO4-(NH4)2SO4-CdSO4, the neg. electrode is inert metal such as Cu foil, and the pos. electrode is an insol. org. material, tetrachloro-p-benzoquinone (chloranil). Typically, the electrolyte is continuously circulated to pass though the cells by a single pump as the battery is on duty. There is no requirement for a membrane. Tetrachloro-p-benzo-hydroquinone is oxidized to chloranil at pos. electrode and the Cd ions is reduced to Cd and electroplated onto the neg. electrode during charge. The reverse occurs during discharge. Results obtained with a small lab. cell show that high efficiencies can be achieved with an av. coulombic efficiency of 99% and energy efficiency of 82% over 100 cycles at the c.d. of 10 mA cm-2.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXotFWnt7w%253D&md5=78f194f718b5da002f557ae909f51bab

        Huskinson, B.; Nawar, S.; Gerhardt, M. R.; Aziz, M. J. Novel Quinone-Based Couples for Flow Batteries. ECS Trans. 2013, 53, 101– 105,  DOI: 10.1149/05307.0101ecst

        Novel quinone-based couples for flow batteries
        Huskinson, Brian; Nawar, Saraf; Gerhardt, Michael R.; Aziz, Michael
        ECS Transactions (2013), 53 (7, Stationary and Large Scale Electrical Energy Storage 2), 101-105, 6 pp.CODEN: ECSTF8; ISSN:1938-5862. (Electrochemical Society)
        Flow batteries are of interest for low-cost grid-scale elec. energy storage in the face of rising electricity prodn. from intermittent renewables like wind and solar. We report on investigations of redox couples based on the reversible protonation of small org. mols. called quinones. These mols. can be very inexpensive and may therefore offer a low cost per kWh of elec. energy storage. Furthermore they are known to rapidly undergo oxidn. and redn. with high reversibility under some conditions, suggesting the possibility of high c.d. operation, which could lead to low cost per kW. We report cyclic voltammetry measurements for 1,4-parabenzoquinone in neutral pH aq. soln. using a three-electrode setup. We report full fuel cell measurements as well, utilizing p-benzoquinone in an acidic soln. as a pos. electrode material and a hydrogen neg. electrode, where current densities in excess of 240 mA cm-2 have been achieved to date. These initial results indicate that the quinone/hydroquinone redox couple is a promising candidate for use in redox flow batteries.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXos1Ogt7Y%253D&md5=acfde3e2a0df8f7901159d22395626cb

        Yang, B.; Hoober-Burkhardt, L.; Krishnamoorthy, S.; Murali, A.; Prakash, G. K. S.; Narayanan, S. R. High-Performance Aqueous Organic Flow Battery with Quinone-Based Redox Couples at Both Electrodes. J. Electrochem. Soc. 2016, 163, A1442– A1449,  DOI: 10.1149/2.1371607jes
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar

        High-Performance Aqueous Organic Flow Battery with Quinone-Based Redox Couples at Both Electrodes
        Yang, Bo; Hoober-Burkhardt, Lena; Krishnamoorthy, Sankarganesh; Murali, Advaith; Prakash, G. K. Surya; Narayanan, S. R.
        Journal of the Electrochemical Society (2016), 163 (7), A1442-A1449CODEN: JESOAN; ISSN:0013-4651. (Electrochemical Society)
        The authors demonstrated the repeated cycling of a redox flow cell based on H2O-sol. org. redox couples (ORBAT) at high voltage efficiency, coulombic efficiency and power d. These cells were successfully operated with 4,5-dihydroxybenzene-1,3-disulfonic acid (BQDS) at the pos. electrode and anthraquinone-2,6-disulfonic acid (AQDS) at the neg. electrode. Redn. of the voltage losses arising from mass transport limitations, and understanding of the chem. transformations of BQDS during charging led to these improvements in performance. The specific advances reported here include the use of org. redox couples in the free-acid form, improvements to the flow field configuration, and novel high-surface-area graphite-felt electrode structures. The authors have identified various steps in the chem. and electrochem. transformations of BQDS during the 1st few cycles. Also the crossover of the reactants through the membrane was not significant. The performance improvements and new understanding presented here will hasten the development of ORBAT as an inexpensive and sustainable soln. for large-scale elec. energy storage.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XnvFWisL8%253D&md5=e0a2a6f78533a4ea712449f1d7f07a47

        Hoober-Burkhardt, L.; Krishnamoorthy, S.; Yang, B.; Murali, A.; Nirmalchandar, A.; Prakash, G. K. S.; Narayanan, S. R. A new Michael-reaction-resistant benzoquinone for aqueous organic redox flow batteries. J. Electrochem. Soc. 2017, 164, A600– A607,  DOI: 10.1149/2.0351704jes
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar

        A New Michael-Reaction-Resistant Benzoquinone for Aqueous Organic Redox Flow Batteries
        Hoober-Burkhardt, Lena; Krishnamoorthy, Sankarganesh; Yang, Bo; Murali, Advaith; Nirmalchandar, Archith; Prakash, G. K. Surya; Narayanan, S. R.
        Journal of the Electrochemical Society (2017), 164 (4), A600-A607CODEN: JESOAN; ISSN:0013-4651. (Electrochemical Society)
        The synthesis, characterization and properties are reported of 3,6-dihydroxy-2,4-dimethylbenzenesulfonic acid (DHDMBS) as a new pos. side electrolyte material for aq. org. redox flow batteries (ORBAT). This material is synthesized in pure form in high yield and its structure is confirmed. It was detd. that the std. redn. potential, the rate const. of the redox reaction, and the diffusion coeff. are ideally suited for use in ORBAT. Specifically, DHDMBS overcomes the major issue of Michael reaction with water faced with 4,5-dihydroxybenzene-1,3-disulfonic acid (BQDS) and similar unsubstituted benzoquinones in the selection of pos. electrolyte materials. The DHDMBS can be synthesized relatively inexpensively. The chem. stability is demonstrated of DHDMBS to repeated electrochem. cycling through NMR and electrochem. studies proving the absence of products of the Michael reaction. A flow cell with DHDMBS and anthraquinone-2,7-disulfonic acid has now been shown to operate close to 100% coulombic efficiency for over 25 cycles when continuously cycled at 100 mA/cm2, and can sustain current densities as high as 500 mA/cm2 without noticeable chem. degrdn. However, there was a slow decrease in the capacity of the flow cell attributable to the crossover of DHDMBS from the pos. side of the cell. Thus, the present study has shown DHDMBS as a promising candidate for the pos. side material for an all-org. aq. redox flow battery in acidic media, and the future efforts will focus on understanding the crossover of DHDMBS and the effects of long-term cycling.

        Molecular Engineering of an Alkaline Naphthoquinone Flow Battery
        Tong, Liuchuan; Goulet, Marc-Antoni; Tabor, Daniel P.; Kerr, Emily F.; De Porcellinis, Diana; Fell, Eric M.; Aspuru-Guzik, Alan; Gordon, Roy G.; Aziz, Michael J.
        ACS Energy Letters (2019), 4 (8), 1880-1887CODEN: AELCCP; ISSN:2380-8195. (American Chemical Society)
        Aq. org. redox flow batteries (AORFBs) have recently gained significant attention as a potential candidate for grid-scale elec. energy storage. Successful implementation of this technol. will require redox-active org. mols. with many desired properties. Here we introduce a naphthoquinone dimer, bislawsone, as the redox-active material in a neg. potential electrolyte (negolyte) for an AORFB. This dimerization strategy substantially improves the performance of the electrolyte vs. that of the lawsone monomer in terms of soly., stability, reversible capacity, permeability, and cell voltage. An AORFB pairing bislawsone with a ferri/ferrocyanide pos. electrolyte delivers an open-circuit voltage of 1.05 V and cycles at a c.d. of 300 mA/cm2 with a negolyte concn. of 2 M electrons in alk. soln. We detd. the degrdn. mechanism for the naphthoquinone-based electrolyte using chem. anal. and predicted theor. electrolytes based on naphthoquinones that will be even more stable.

        A Water-Miscible Quinone Flow Battery with High Volumetric Capacity and Energy Density
        Jin, Shijian; Jing, Yan; Kwabi, David G.; Ji, Yunlong; Tong, Liuchuan; De Porcellinis, Diana; Goulet, Marc-Antoni; Pollack, Daniel A.; Gordon, Roy G.; Aziz, Michael J.
        ACS Energy Letters (2019), 4 (6), 1342-1348CODEN: AELCCP; ISSN:2380-8195. (American Chemical Society)
        A water-miscible anthraquinone with polyethylene glycol (PEG)-based solubilizing groups is introduced as the redox-active mol. in a neg. electrolyte (negolyte) for aq. redox flow batteries, exhibiting the highest volumetric capacity among aq. org. negolytes. A series of PEG-substituted anthraquinones (PEGAQs) are synthesized and screened and carefully studied one of its isomers, 1,8-bis(2-(2-(2-hydroxyethoxy)ethoxy)ethoxy)anthracene-9,10-dione (AQ-1,8-3E-OH), which has high electrochem. reversibility and is completely miscible in water of any pH. A negolyte contg. 1.5 M AQ-1,8-3E-OH, when paired with a ferrocyanide-based pos. electrolyte across an inexpensive, nonfluorinated permselective polymer membrane at pH 7, exhibits an open-circuit potential of 1.0 V, a volumetric capacity of 80.4 Ah/L, and an energy d. of 25.2 Wh/L.

        High-Performance Alkaline Organic Redox Flow Batteries Based on 2-Hydroxy-3-carboxy-1,4-naphthoquinone
        Wang, Caixing; Yang, Zhen; Wang, Yanrong; Zhao, Peiyang; Yan, Wen; Zhu, Guoyin; Ma, Lianbo; Yu, Bo; Wang, Lei; Li, Guigen; Liu, Jie; Jin, Zhong
        ACS Energy Letters (2018), 3 (10), 2404-2409CODEN: AELCCP; ISSN:2380-8195. (American Chemical Society)
        Aq. redox flow batteries (ARFBs) based on the electrolyte solns. of redox-active org. mols. are very attractive for the application of large-scale electrochem. energy storage. We propose a high-performance ARFB system using 2-hydroxy-3-carboxy-1,4-naphthoquinone (2,3-HCNQ) and K4Fe(CN)6 as the anolyte and catholyte active species, resp. The 2,3-HCNQ mol. exhibits high soly. and can carry out a reversible 2-electron redox process with rapid redox kinetics. The assembled 2,3-HCNQ/K4Fe(CN)6 ARFB delivered a cell voltage of 1.02 V and realized a peak power d. of 0.255 W/cm2. The 2,3-HCNQ/K4Fe(CN)6 ARFB can be stably operated at a c.d. of 100 mA/cm2 for long-term cycling (with a capacity retention of ∼94.7% after 100 cycles).

        Yang, B.; Hoober-Burkhardt, L.; Wang, F.; Surya Prakash, G. K.; Narayanan, S. R. An inexpensive aqueous flow battery for large-scale electrical energy storage based on water-soluble organic redox couples. J. Electrochem. Soc. 2014, 161, A1371– A1380,  DOI: 10.1149/2.1001409jes

        An Inexpensive Aqueous Flow Battery for Large-Scale Electrical Energy Storage Based on Water-Soluble Organic Redox Couples
        Yang, Bo; Hoober-Burkhardt, Lena; Wang, Fang; Surya Prakash, G. K.; Narayanan, S. R.
        Journal of the Electrochemical Society (2014), 161 (9), A1371-A1380CODEN: JESOAN; ISSN:0013-4651. (Electrochemical Society)
        We introduce a novel Org. Redox Flow Battery (ORBAT), for meeting the demanding requirements of cost, eco-friendliness, and durability for large-scale energy storage. ORBAT employs two different water-sol. org. redox couples on the pos. and neg. side of a flow battery. Redox couples such as quinones are particularly attractive for this application. No precious metal catalyst is needed because of the fast proton-coupled electron transfer processes. Furthermore, in acid media, the quinones exhibit good chem. stability. These properties render quinone-based redox couples very attractive for high-efficiency metal-free rechargeable batteries. We demonstrate the rechargeability of ORBAT with anthraquinone-2-sulfonic acid or anthraquinone-2,6-disulfonic acid on the neg. side, and 1,2-dihydrobenzoquinone-3,5-disulfonic acid on the pos. side. The ORBAT cell uses a membrane-electrode assembly configuration similar to that used in polymer electrolyte fuel cells. Such a battery can be charged and discharged multiple times at high faradaic efficiency without any noticeable degrdn. of performance. We show that soly. and mass transport properties of the reactants and products are paramount to achieving high current densities and high efficiency. The ORBAT configuration presents a unique opportunity for developing an inexpensive and sustainable metal-free rechargeable battery for large-scale elec. energy storage.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXhtFOnsrnO&md5=1bd4bc1ac4fccd7b9d18ea3dce981eb9

        Zhang, S.; Li, X.; Chu, D. An Organic Electroactive Material for Flow Batteries. Electrochim. Acta 2016, 190, 737– 743,  DOI: 10.1016/j.electacta.2015.12.139

        An Organic Electroactive Material for Flow Batteries
        Zhang, Shu; Li, Xin; Chu, Dandan
        Electrochimica Acta (2016), 190 (), 737-743CODEN: ELCAAV; ISSN:0013-4686. (Elsevier Ltd.)
        An inexpensive, abundant electroactive org. mol., 3,4-Dihydroxy-9,10-anthraquinone-2-sulfonic acid (ARS) is proposed to serve as the redox active material in the neg. side of flow batteries. The electrochem. characteristics and mass transport properties are discussed in this work. The diffusion coeff. of ARS is calcd. as 2.14 × 10-6 cm2 s-1, and the kinetic rate const. of ARS is further measured as 3.6 × 10-3 cm s-1, which is faster than other metal redox active species used in flow batteries, such as Fe3+/Fe2+, Cr3+/Cr2+, VO+2/VO2+, and Ce4+/Ce3+. Unlike metal redox materials, ARS will not suffer from the resource constraints. Combining 1,2-benzoquinone-3,5-disulfonic acid (BQDS) as the pos. electroactive species and H2SO4 soln. as the supporting electrolyte, the different charging-discharging behavior and the polarization curves exhibited a good performance with our lab. design flow cell. It can be concluded that the ARS presents a unique opportunity for developing a promising and cost-effective alternative for metal-free flow batteries.

        Wedege, K.; Dražević, E.; Konya, D.; Bentien, A. Organic Redox Species in Aqueous Flow Batteries: Redox Potentials, Chemical Stability and Solubility. Sci. Rep. 2016, 6, 39101,  DOI: 10.1038/srep39101
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        104
        Organic Redox Species in Aqueous Flow Batteries: Redox Potentials, Chemical Stability and Solubility
        Wedege, Kristina; Drazevic, Emil; Konya, Denes; Bentien, Anders
        Scientific Reports (2016), 6 (), 39101CODEN: SRCEC3; ISSN:2045-2322. (Nature Publishing Group)
        Org. mols. are currently investigated as redox species for aq. low-cost redox flow batteries (RFBs). The envisioned features of using org. redox species are low cost and increased flexibility with respect to tailoring redox potential and soly. from mol. engineering of side groups on the org. redox-active species. In this paper 33, mainly quinone-based, compds. are studied experimentially in terms of pH dependent redox potential, soly. and stability, combined with single cell battery RFB tests on selected redox pairs. Data shows that both the soly. and redox potential are detd. by the position of the side groups and only to a small extent by the no. of side groups. Addnl., the chem. stability and possible degrdn. mechanisms leading to capacity loss over time are discussed. The main challenge for the development of all-org. RFBs is to identify a redox pair for the pos. side with sufficiently high stability and redox potential that enables battery cell potentials above 1 V.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XitFGjtrjP&md5=e95a2c6c3325dbaa572dcf0b96595410

        Leung, P. K.; Martin, T.; Shah, A. A.; Anderson, M. A.; Palma, J. Membrane-less organic-inorganic aqueous flow batteries with improved cell potential. Chem. Commun. 2016, 52, 14270– 14273,  DOI: 10.1039/C6CC07692K
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar

        Membrane-less organic-inorganic aqueous flow batteries with improved cell potential
        Leung, P. K.; Martin, T.; Shah, A. A.; Anderson, M. A.; Palma, J.
        Chemical Communications (Cambridge, United Kingdom) (2016), 52 (99), 14270-14273CODEN: CHCOFS; ISSN:1359-7345. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A membrane-less org.-inorg. flow battery based on zinc and quinone species is proposed. By virtue of the slow dissoln. rate of the deposited anode (<11.5 mg h-1 cm-2), the battery has a cell voltage of ca. 1.52 V with an av. energy efficiency of ca. 73% at 30 mA cm-2 over 12 cycles.

        Xu, Y.; Zheng, Y.; Wang, C.; Chen, Q. An All-Organic Aqueous Battery Powered by Adsorbed Quinone. ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces 2019, 11, 23222– 23228,  DOI: 10.1021/acsami.9b05159
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        106
        An All-Organic Aqueous Battery Powered by Adsorbed Quinone
        Xu, Yuan; Zheng, Yiting; Wang, Congcheng; Chen, Qing
        ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces (2019), 11 (26), 23222-23228CODEN: AAMICK; ISSN:1944-8244. (American Chemical Society)
        The need for cost-effective, safe energy storage has led to unprecedentedly complex designs of materials and structures to meet stringent requirements. Yet, it remains a question whether the manufg. is afforded of these new materials and structures at a practical cost. Here, a new approach is introduced toward an all-org. aq. battery through one-step, soln.-phase adsorption. In this battery, two quinone mols. with different redox potentials adsorb onto two porous carbon electrodes to serve as the neg. and the pos. electrodes. For the neg. side, cyclic voltammetry shows a high surface coverage of 66 pmol/cm2 for the adsorbed quinone (anthraquinone-2,7-disulfonate), which enables a stable capacity of 77 mAh/g. The full battery, operating in 1 M sulfuric acid, delivers > 80% of its capacity at rates of ≤ 60C, and it retains > 70% of the capacity after 600 cycles. As the battery adopts the typical build of a supercapacitor, this adsorption-based approach should apply broadly to achieve low-cost, safe storage. The work also provides a quant. account of the electrochem. of quinone adsorbed on carbon, which bears significance in the exploitation of quinone mols. in various electrochem. applications.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1MXhtV2lsbzP&md5=52c5e428ad0b7f8a5dd05b802c75dcfd
      107. 107
        Preger, Y.; Gerken, J. B.; Biswas, S.; Anson, C. W.; Johnson, M. R.; Root, T. W.; Stahl, S. S. Quinone-Mediated Electrochemical O2 Reduction Accessing High Power Density with an Off-Electrode Co-N/C Catalyst. Joule 2018, 2, 2722– 2731,  DOI: 10.1016/j.joule.2018.09.010
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        107
        Quinone-Mediated Electrochemical O2 Reduction Accessing High Power Density with an Off-Electrode Co-N/C Catalyst
        Preger, Yuliya; Gerken, James B.; Biswas, Sourav; Anson, Colin W.; Johnson, Mathew R.; Root, Thatcher W.; Stahl, Shannon S.
        Joule (2018), 2 (12), 2722-2731CODEN: JOULBR; ISSN:2542-4351. (Cell Press)
        New methods for interconversion of elec. and chem. energy are crucial to addressing emerging challenges in renewable energy storage and conversion. Dissolved redox mediators provide an effective means to transport electrons (and protons) between an electrode and catalysts that are not in direct phys. contact with an electrode. Mediators are widely implemented in biofuel cells, but such devices typically exhibit low power densities. Here, we report the development of a tetrasubstituted quinone mediator that exhibits excellent stability under strongly acidic conditions and supports electrochem. redn. of O2 at an off-electrode heterogeneous cobalt catalyst contained within a packed-bed reactor. Efficient oxidn. of the hydroquinone by O2 in the reactor provides the basis for mediator regeneration, and an integrated "flow-cathode" fuel cell system supports high power densities. These results establish the combination of org. mediators with off-electrode heterogeneous catalysts as a versatile platform for development of new electrode-driven chem. redox transformations.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXisFOktb3O&md5=48050883548e1fb68e546fe3bc6de01c
      108. 108
        Carney, T. J.; Collins, S. J.; Moore, J. S.; Brushett, F. R. Concentration-Dependent Dimerization of Anthraquinone Disulfonic Acid and Its Impact on Charge Storage. Chem. Mater. 2017, 29, 4801– 4810,  DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemmater.7b00616
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        108
        Concentration-Dependent Dimerization of Anthraquinone Disulfonic Acid and Its Impact on Charge Storage
        Carney, Thomas J.; Collins, Steven J.; Moore, Jeffrey S.; Brushett, Fikile R.
        Chemistry of Materials (2017), 29 (11), 4801-4810CODEN: CMATEX; ISSN:0897-4756. (American Chemical Society)
        9,10-Anthraquinone-2,7-disulfonic acid (AQDS) is considered a benchmark active material for aq. org. redox flow batteries. At low concn., AQDS demonstrates 2-electron transfer at near ideal electrochem. reversibility; however, at higher concn., AQDS displays more complex behavior presumably due to the emergence of intermol. reactions. Here, the authors systematically examine the electrochem. and phys. properties of AQDS solns. using a suite of electrochem., anal., and spectroscopic techniques. Depending on the AQDS pretreatment, concn., soln. pH, and electrolyte compn., coupled chem. and electrochem. reactions lead to different charge storage capabilities. To elucidate the underlying cause of these differences, the authors performed various pre-treatments of AQDS, examd. chem. speciation by NMR, and studied the corresponding electrochem. properties through cyclic voltammetry and bulk electrolysis. In all cases, reversible intermol. dimerization was detected at soln. concns. >10 mM. Also, the charge state of the formed dimers was dependent on the AQDS pretreatment and the soln. pH. Under acidic conditions, 1.5 electrons per mol. of AQDS were reversibly accessible, whereas under buffered mild-alk. conditions, only one electron per mol. of AQDS was accessible. Because of insufficient p concn., AQDS did not cycle reversibly in unbuffered neutral electrolyte. Even when employing chem. oxidants during a chem. titrn., charge storage of 2 electrons per mol. could not be realized. The authors hypothesize that adduct formation between AQDS and CO2, along with soln. pH, play important roles in the charge accessibility.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXotVGmsLw%253D&md5=9136a3dc58d7b524bd9ca74e62935a3e
      109. 109
        Wiberg, C.; Carney, T. J.; Brushett, F.; Ahlberg, E.; Wang, E. Dimerization of 9,10-anthraquinone-2,7-Disulfonic acid (AQDS). Electrochim. Acta 2019, 317, 478– 485,  DOI: 10.1016/j.electacta.2019.05.134
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        109
        Dimerization of 9,10-anthraquinone-2,7-Disulfonic acid (AQDS)
        Wiberg, Cedrik; Carney, Thomas J.; Brushett, Fikile; Ahlberg, Elisabet; Wang, Ergang
        Electrochimica Acta (2019), 317 (), 478-485CODEN: ELCAAV; ISSN:0013-4686. (Elsevier Ltd.)
        The redox flow battery is a leading candidate to supply society with large-scale energy storage. In the category of aq. org. redox flow batteries, 9,10-anthraquinone-2,7-disulfonic acid (AQDS) is considered a top-performing mol. and shows ideal electrochem. behavior at low concns. around 1 mM. However, its behavior at higher concns. was rarely studied. In this work, the correlation between concn. and electrochem. capacity is evaluated for AQDS in 1 M H2SO4 and 1 M alk. sodium carbonate buffer, employing cyclic voltammetry, rotating disk electrode voltammetry and diffusion NMR. It was found that an electrochem. inactive dimer was formed by the unreduced AQDS mols., with dimerization equil. consts. detd. to be K = 5 M-1 for the acidic electrolyte and 8 M-1 for the alk. one, significantly inhibiting full electrochem. utilization of the system. However, upon redn. of the bulk material, the dimerization will shift in favor of monomer or quinhydrone formation, possibly alleviating the impediment to redn. Finally, it was found that the dimerization could be decreased slightly by increasing the temp. of the system.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1MXhtFKjt7bO&md5=b120417acba71fe3f933d2bc307b4886
      110. 110
        Gerhardt, M. R.; Beh, E. S.; Tong, L.; Gordon, R. G.; Aziz, M. J. Comparison of Capacity Retention Rates During Cycling of Quinone-Bromide Flow Batteries. MRS Adv. 2017, 2, 431– 438,  DOI: 10.1557/adv.2016.667
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        110
        Comparison of Capacity Retention Rates During Cycling of Quinone-Bromide Flow Batteries
        Gerhardt, Michael R.; Beh, Eugene S.; Tong, Liuchuan; Gordon, Roy G.; Aziz, Michael J.
        MRS Advances (2017), 2 (8), 431-438CODEN: MARDCQ; ISSN:2059-8521. (Cambridge University Press)
        We use cyclic charge-discharge expts. to evaluate the capacity retention rates of two quinone-bromide flow batteries (QBFBs). These aq. QBFBs use a neg. electrolyte contg. either anthraquinone-2,7-disulfonic acid (AQDS) or anthraquinone-2-sulfonic acid (AQS) dissolved in sulfuric acid, and a pos. electrolyte contg. bromine and hydrobromic acid. We find that the AQS cell exhibits a significantly lower capacity retention rate than the AQDS cell. The obsd. AQS capacity fade is corroborated by NMR evidence that suggests the formation of hydroxylated products in the electrolyte in place of AQS. We further cycle the AQDS cell and observe a capacity fade rate extrapolating to 30% loss of active species after 5000 cycles. After about 180 cycles, bromine crossover leads to sufficient electrolyte imbalance to accelerate the capacity fade rate, indicating that the actual realization of long cycle life will require bromine rebalancing or a membrane less permeable than Nafion to mol. bromine.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXlvF2kuro%253D&md5=0e2b5e394e9885b888608ee01b454661
      111. 111
        Wedege, K.; Azevedo, J.; Khataee, A.; Bentien, A.; Mendes, A. Direct Solar Charging of an Organic-Inorganic, Stable, and Aqueous Alkaline Redox Flow Battery with a Hematite Photoanode. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2016, 55, 7142– 7147,  DOI: 10.1002/anie.201602451
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        111
        Direct Solar Charging of an Organic-Inorganic, Stable, and Aqueous Alkaline Redox Flow Battery with a Hematite Photoanode
        Wedege, Kristina; Azevedo, Joao; Khataee, Amirreza; Bentien, Anders; Mendes, Adelio
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2016), 55 (25), 7142-7147CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        The intermittent nature of the sunlight and its increasing contribution to electricity generation is fostering the energy storage research. Direct solar charging of an auspicious type of redox flow battery could make solar energy directly and efficiently dispatchable. The first solar aq. alk. redox flow battery using low cost and environmentally safe materials is demonstrated. The electrolytes consist of the redox couples ferrocyanide and anthraquinone-2,7-disulfonate in sodium hydroxide soln., yielding a std. cell potential of 0.74 V. Photovoltage enhancement strategies are demonstrated for the ferrocyanide-hematite junction by employing an annealing treatment and growing a layer of a conductive polyaniline polymer on the electrode surface, which decreases electron-hole recombination.

        Li, W.; Fu, H. C.; Li, L.; Caban-Acevedo, M.; He, J. H.; Jin, S. Integrated Photoelectrochemical Solar Energy Conversion and Organic Redox Flow Battery Devices. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2016, 55, 13104– 13108,  DOI: 10.1002/anie.201606986
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        112
        Integrated Photoelectrochemical Solar Energy Conversion and Organic Redox Flow Battery Devices
        Li, Wenjie; Fu, Hui-Chun; Li, Linsen; Caban-Acevedo, Miguel; He, Jr-Hau; Jin, Song
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2016), 55 (42), 13104-13108CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        Building on regenerative photoelectrochem. solar cells and emerging electrochem. redox flow batteries (RFBs), more efficient, scalable, compact, and cost-effective hybrid energy conversion and storage devices could be realized. An integrated photoelectrochem. solar energy conversion and electrochem. storage device is developed by integrating regenerative silicon solar cells and 9,10-anthraquinone-2,7-disulfonic acid (AQDS)/1,2-benzoquinone-3,5-disulfonic acid (BQDS) RFBs. The device can be directly charged by solar light without external bias, and discharged like normal RFBs with an energy storage d. of 1.15 Wh L-1 and a solar-to-output electricity efficiency (SOEE) of 1.7 % over many cycles. The concept exploits a previously undeveloped design connecting two major energy technologies and promises a general approach for storing solar energy electrochem. with high theor. storage capacity and efficiency.

        McKone, J. R.; DiSalvo, F. J.; Abruna, H. D. Solar energy conversion, storage, and release using an integrated solar-driven redox flow battery. J. Mater. Chem. A 2017, 5, 5362– 5372,  DOI: 10.1039/C7TA00555E
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        113
        Solar energy conversion, storage, and release using an integrated solar-driven redox flow battery
        McKone, James R.; Di Salvo, Francis J.; Abruna, Hector D.
        Journal of Materials Chemistry A: Materials for Energy and Sustainability (2017), 5 (11), 5362-5372CODEN: JMCAET; ISSN:2050-7496. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        We have conceptualized and demonstrated a device that combines the functions of a solar photovoltaic cell and a redox flow battery, which we call the solar flow battery (SFB). Our lab-scale device is based on a cryst. n-WSe2 light absorber, carbon auxiliary electrodes, an iodide pos. electrolyte, and an anthraquinone sulfonate neg. electrolyte. We have designed a two-compartment flow cell and used it to independently characterize the electrochem. properties of the electrolytes, the photoelectrochem. properties of the n-WSe2 absorber, and the charge-discharge performance of the full SFB. Our WSe2-based SFB is as simple to construct as a water-splitting photoanode assembly, but it exhibits markedly higher energy conversion efficiency and also accommodates time-shifted recovery of the stored energy as electricity.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXjtlyks78%253D&md5=545aa34ec38ddc816ceebb34adad0dcd

        Kwabi, D. G.; Wong, A. A.; Aziz, M. J. Rational Evaluation and Cycle Life Improvement of Quinone-Based Aqueous Flow Batteries Guided by In-Line Optical Spectrophotometry. J. Electrochem. Soc. 2018, 165, A1770– A1776,  DOI: 10.1149/2.0791809jes
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        114
        Rational Evaluation and Cycle Life Improvement of Quinone-Based Aqueous Flow Batteries Guided by In-Line Optical Spectrophotometry
        Kwabi, David G.; Wong, Andrew A.; Aziz, Michael J.
        Journal of the Electrochemical Society (2018), 165 (9), A1770-A1776CODEN: JESOAN; ISSN:0013-4651. (Electrochemical Society)
        The authors measure electrolyte concn. and state-of-charge in real time in an operating aq. anthraquinone-based flow battery using in-line optical spectrophotometry. By capitalizing on the linear transition in absorption spectra between oxidized and reduced states, discontinuous capacity fade rates in redox flow batteries can be caused by a transition from one capacity-limiting electrolyte to the other, which is caused by reactant crossover. With this insight, the authors demonstrate an electrolyte-balancing scheme, which can be broadly applicable to flow battery systems with asym. electrolyte crossover rates.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXht1ekt7%252FP&md5=e18aefbf6c521d340e171056813a8a90
      115. 115
        Xie, W.; Darling, R. M.; Perry, M. L. Processing and Pretreatment Effects on Vanadium Transport in Nafion Membranes. J. Electrochem. Soc. 2016, 163, A5084– A5089,  DOI: 10.1149/2.0111601jes
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        115
        Processing and Pretreatment Effects on Vanadium Transport in Nafion Membranes
        Xie, Wei; Darling, Robert M.; Perry, Mike L.
        Journal of the Electrochemical Society (2016), 163 (1), A5084-A5089CODEN: JESOAN; ISSN:0013-4651. (Electrochemical Society)
        This work describes how manufg. processes and pretreatments affect the proton cond. and vanadyl permeability of Nafion and how these properties are altered by running in a cell. Five Nafion membranes were examd.: reinforced XL100, dispersion cast NR211 and NR212, and extruded N115 and N117. The membranes were subjected to pretreatments that included annealing at 120°C and immersing in ambient temp. and boiling water and sulfuric acid. Vanadyl permeability varied by ∼15X with pretreatment and ∼3X with manufg. process. Variations in ionic cond. were comparatively modest: ∼1.5X with pretreatment and ∼1.2X with processing. Differences in permeability can be eliminated by annealing the extruded membranes above their glass-transition temp. or by immersing in boiling sulfuric acid. The differences induced by processing and pretreatments were largely absent from membranes removed from vanadium redox cells subjected to repeated charge/discharge cycles.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        Chang, Z.; Henkensmeier, D.; Chen, R. One-Step Cationic Grafting of 4-Hydroxy-TEMPO and its Application in a Hybrid Redox Flow Battery with a Crosslinked PBI Membrane. ChemSusChem 2017, 10, 3193– 3197,  DOI: 10.1002/cssc.201701060

        One-step cationic grafting of 4-Hydroxy-TEMPO and aplication in hybrid redox flow battery with cosslinked PBI membrane
        Chang, Zhenjun; Henkensmeier, Dirk; Chen, Ruiyong
        ChemSusChem (2017), 10 (16), 3193-3197CODEN: CHEMIZ; ISSN:1864-5631. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        By using a one-step epoxide ring-opening reaction between 4-hydroxy-2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidine 1-oxyl (4-hydroxy-TEMPO) and glycidyltrimethylammonium cation (GTMA+), we synthesized a cation-grafted TEMPO (g+-TEMPO) and studied its electrochem. performance against a Zn2+/Zn anode in a hybrid redox flow battery. To conduct Cl- counter anions, a crosslinked methylated polybenzimidazole (PBI) membrane was prepd. and placed between the catholyte and anolyte. Compared to 4-hydroxy-TEMPO, the pos. charged g+- TEMPO exhibits enhanced reaction kinetics. Moreover, flow battery tests with g+-TEMPO show improved Coulombic, voltage, and energy efficiencies and cycling stability over 140 cycles. Crossover of active species through the membrane was not detected.

        A Long-Lifetime All-Organic Aqueous Flow Battery Utilizing TMAP-TEMPO Radical
        Liu, Yahua; Goulet, Marc-Antoni; Tong, Liuchuan; Liu, Yazhi; Ji, Yunlong; Wu, Liang; Gordon, Roy G.; Aziz, Michael J.; Yang, Zhengjin; Xu, Tongwen
        Chem (2019), 5 (7), 1861-1870CODEN: CHEMVE; ISSN:2451-9294. (Cell Press)
        The massive-scale integration of renewable electricity into the power grid is impeded by its intrinsic intermittency. The aq. org. redox flow battery (AORFB) rises as a potential storage soln.; however, the choice of pos. electrolytes is limited, and the aq.-sol. org. pos. redox-active species reported to date have short lifetimes. Here we report a stable org. mol. for the pos. terminal, 4-[3-(trimethylammonio)propoxy]-2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidine-1-oxyl (TMAP-TEMPO) chloride, exhibiting high (4.62 M) aq. soly. When operated in a practical AORFB against a neg. electrolyte comprising BTMAP-viologen at neutral pH, the flow cell displayed an open-circuit voltage of 1.1 V and a Coulombic efficiency of >99.73%. The capacity retention rate is among the highest of all-org. AORFBs reported to date, at 99.993% per cycle over 1,000 consecutive cycles; the temporal capacity fade rate of 0.026% per h is independent of concn.

        TEMPO/Phenazine Combi-Molecule: A Redox-Active Material for Symmetric Aqueous Redox-Flow Batteries
        Winsberg, Jan; Stolze, Christian; Muench, Simon; Liedl, Ferenc; Hager, Martin D.; Schubert, Ulrich S.
        ACS Energy Letters (2016), 1 (5), 976-980CODEN: AELCCP; ISSN:2380-8195. (American Chemical Society)
        The combination of 2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidinyl-N-oxyl and phenazine yields an org. redox-active material for redox-flow battery applications. This combined mol. (combi-mol.) features a redox voltage of 1.2 V and facilitates the use of aq. electrolytes. It was synthesized from cost-efficient starting materials, electrochem. characterized and applied as charge-storage material in a sym. aq. redox-flow battery.
