        Janoschka, T.; Martin, N.; Martin, U.; Friebe, C.; Morgenstern, S.; Hiller, H.; Hager, M. D.; Schubert, U. S. An aqueous, polymer-based redox-flow battery using non-corrosive, safe, and low-cost materials. Nature 2015, 527, 78– 81,  DOI: 10.1038/nature15746
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        120
        An aqueous, polymer-based redox-flow battery using non-corrosive, safe, and low-cost materials
        Janoschka, Tobias; Martin, Norbert; Martin, Udo; Friebe, Christian; Morgenstern, Sabine; Hiller, Hannes; Hager, Martin D.; Schubert, Ulrich S.
        Nature (London, United Kingdom) (2015), 527 (7576), 78-81CODEN: NATUAS; ISSN:0028-0836. (Nature Publishing Group)
        For renewable energy sources such as solar, wind, and hydroelec. to be effectively used in the grid of the future, flexible and scalable energy-storage solns. are necessary to mitigate output fluctuations. Redox-flow batteries (RFBs) were 1st built in the 1940s and are considered a promising large-scale energy-storage technol. A limited no. of redox-active materials-mainly metal salts, corrosive halogens, and low-molar-mass org. compds.-have been studied as active materials, and only a few membrane materials, such as Nafion, have been considered for RFBs. However, for systems that are intended for both domestic and large-scale use, safety and cost must be taken into account as well as energy d. and capacity, particularly regarding long-term access to metal resources, which places limits on the Li-ion-based and V-based RFB development. Here the authors describe an affordable, safe, and scalable battery system, which uses org. polymers as the charge-storage material in combination with inexpensive dialysis membranes, which sep. the anode and the cathode by the retention of the nonmetallic, active (macro-mol.) species, and an aq. NaCl soln. as the electrolyte. This H2O- and polymer-based RFB has an energy d. of 10 W hours per L, current densities of up to 100 mA/cm2 and stable long-term cycling capability. The polymer-based RFB the authors present uses an environmentally benign NaCl soln. and cheap, com. available filter membranes instead of highly corrosive acid electrolytes and expensive membrane materials.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXhslynurrN&md5=44665f9a301a89114033ab1fbf7683dd
      121. 121
        Janoschka, T.; Martin, N.; Hager, M. D.; Schubert, U. S. An aqueous redox-flow battery with high capacity and power: the TEMPTMA/MV system. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2016, 55, 14427– 14430,  DOI: 10.1002/anie.201606472
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        121
        Aqueous Redox-Flow Battery with High Capacity and Power: The TEMPTMA/MV System
        Janoschka, Tobias; Martin, Norbert; Hager, Martin D.; Schubert, Ulrich S.
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2016), 55 (46), 14427-14430CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        Redox-flow batteries (RFB) can easily store large amts. of elec. energy and thereby mitigate the fluctuating output of renewable power plants. They are widely discussed as energy-storage solns. for wind and solar farms to improve the stability of the elec. grid. Most common RFB concepts are based on strongly acidic metal-salt solns. or poorly performing orgs. Herein the authors present a battery which employs the highly sol. N,N,N-2,2,6,6-heptamethylpiperidinyl oxy-4-NH4Cl (TEMPTMA) and the viologen deriv. N,N'-dimethyl-4,4-bipyridinium dichloride (MV) in a simple and safe aq. soln. as redox-active materials. The resulting battery using these electrolyte solns. has capacities of 54 A-h L-1, giving a total energy d. of 38 Wh L-1 at a cell voltage of 1.4 V. With peak current densities of up to 200 mA cm-2 the TEMPTMA/MV system is a suitable candidate for compact high-capacity and high-power applications.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

      122. 122
        Luo, J.; Hu, B.; DeBruler, C.; Liu, T. A “π-Conjugation Extended Viologen” as Novel Two-Electron Storage Anolyte for Total Organic Aqueous Redox Flow Battery. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2018, 57, 231– 235,  DOI: 10.1002/anie.201710517
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        122
        A π-Conjugation Extended Viologen as a Two-Electron Storage Anolyte for Total Organic Aqueous Redox Flow Batteries
        Luo, Jian; Hu, Bo; Debruler, Camden; Liu, Tianbiao Leo
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2018), 57 (1), 231-235CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        Extending the conjugation of viologen by a planar thiazolo[5,4-d]thiazole (TTz) framework and functionalizing the pyridinium with hydrophilic ammonium groups yielded a highly water-sol. π-conjugation extended viologen, 4,4'-(thiazolo[5,4-d]thiazole-2,5-diyl)bis(1-(3-(trimethylammonio)propyl)pyridin-1-ium) tetrachloride, [(NPr)2TTz]Cl4 , as a novel 2-electron storage anolyte for aq. org. redox flow battery (AORFB) applications. Its phys. and electrochem. properties were systematically studied. Paired with 4-trimethylammonium-TEMPO (NMe-TEMPO) as catholyte, [(NPr)2TTz]Cl4 enables a 1.44 V AORFB with a theor. energy d. of 53.7 Wh/L. A demonstrated [(NPr)2TTz]Cl4/NMe-TEMPO AORFB delivered an energy efficiency of 70 and 99.97% capacity retention per cycle.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXhvFyjs73N&md5=ed5cae7582ab1808be2dc7a8b5ef0754

        Chang, Z.; Henkensmeier, D.; Chen, R. Shifting redox potential of nitroxyl radical by introducing an imidazolium substituent and its use in aqueous flow batteries. J. Power Sources 2019, 418, 11– 16,  DOI: 10.1016/j.jpowsour.2019.02.028
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        123
        Shifting redox potential of nitroxyl radical by introducing an imidazolium substituent and its use in aqueous flow batteries
        Chang, Zhenjun; Henkensmeier, Dirk; Chen, Ruiyong
        Journal of Power Sources (2019), 418 (), 11-16CODEN: JPSODZ; ISSN:0378-7753. (Elsevier B.V.)
        Imidazolium-grafted nitroxyl radical is synthesized through a simple two-step reaction route, and studied as redox-active catholyte for redox flow batteries. A discharge cell voltage of 1.64 V against a Zn2+/Zn anodic couple in aq. electrolyte has been achieved. Compared to the com. 4-OH-TEMPO and previous work, the excellent chem. and electrochem. stability of the newly synthesized compd. has been confirmed from the enhanced and steady Coulombic efficiency over charge/discharge cycling. Moreover, stable cycling efficiencies and good capacity retention over long-term cycling have been obsd.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        Winsberg, J.; Stolze, C.; Schwenke, A.; Muench, S.; Hager, M. D.; Schubert, U. S.         124
        Aqueous 2,2,6,6-Tetramethylpiperidine-N-oxyl Catholytes for a High-Capacity and High Current Density Oxygen-Insensitive Hybrid-Flow Battery
        Winsberg, Jan; Stolze, Christian; Schwenke, Almut; Muench, Simon; Hager, Martin D.; Schubert, Ulrich S.
        ACS Energy Letters (2017), 2 (2), 411-416CODEN: AELCCP; ISSN:2380-8195. (American Chemical Society)
        Hybrid-flow batteries are a suitable storage technol. for green electricity generated by renewable sources such as wind power and solar energy. Redox-active org. compds. have recently been investigated to improve the traditional metal- and halogen-based technologies. Here the utilization is reported of a 2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidine-N-oxyl (TEMPO) deriv. that is in particular designed for application in semiorg. zinc hybrid-flow batteries. The TEMPO deriv. is synthesized and electrochem. characterized via cyclic voltammetry and rotating disc electrode measurements. This deriv. features a high soly. in aq. electrolytes; thus, volumetric capacities > 20 AhL-1 are achieved. The fabricated hybrid-flow batteries feature over 1100 consecutive charge-discharge cycles at const. capacity retention, and current densities up to 80 mAcm-2 are applied.

        Hu, B.; DeBruler, C.; Rhodes, Z.; Liu, T. L. Long-cycling aqueous organic redox flow battery (AORFB) toward sustainable and safe energy storage. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2017, 139, 1207– 1214,  DOI: 10.1021/jacs.6b10984
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        125
        Long-Cycling Aqueous Organic Redox Flow Battery (AORFB) toward Sustainable and Safe Energy Storage
        Hu, Bo; DeBruler, Camden; Rhodes, Zayn; Liu, T. Leo
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2017), 139 (3), 1207-1214CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        Redox flow batteries (RFBs) are a viable technol. to store renewable energy in the form of electricity that can be supplied to electricity grids. However, wide-spread implementation of traditional RFBs, such as Vanadium and Zn-Br2 RFBs is limited due to a no. of challenges related to materials, including low abundance and high costs of redox active metals, expensive separators, active material crossover, and corrosive and hazardous electrolytes. To address these challenges, a neutral aq. org. redox flow battery (AORFB) technol. is demonstrated utilizing a newly designed cathode electrolyte contg. a highly water-sol. ferrocene mol. Specifically, water sol. (ferrocenylmethyl)trimethylammonium chloride (FcNCl, 4.0 M in H2O, 107.2 Ah/L, and 3.0 M in 2.0 NaCl, 80.4 Ah/L) and N1-ferrocenylmethyl-N1,N1,N2,N2,N2-pentamethylpropane-1,2-diaminium dibromide, (FcN2Br2, 3.1 M in H2O, 83.1 Ah/L, and 2.0 M in 2.0 M NaCl, 53.5 Ah/L) were synthesized through structural decoration of hydrophobic ferrocene with synergetic hydrophilic functionalities including an ammonium cation group and a halide anion. When paired with Me viologen (MV) as an anolyte, resulting FcNCl/MV and FcN2Br2/MV AORFBs were operated in noncorrosive neutral NaCl supporting electrolytes using a low cost anion exchange membrane. These ferrocene/MV AORFBs are characterized as having high theor. energy d. (45.5 Wh/L), and excellent cycling performance from 40-100 mA/cm2. Notably, the FcNCl/MV AORFBs (demonstrated at 7.0 and 9.9 Wh/L) exhibited unprecedented long cycling performance, 700 cycles at 60 mA/cm2 with 99.99% capacity retention per cycle, and delivered power d. up to 125 mW/cm2. These AORFBs are built from earth abundant elements and environmentally benign, thus represent a promising choice for sustainable and safe energy storage.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XitV2nurfK&md5=0de6d3576463a0604d10018443fb3cea
      126. 126
        Gong, K.; Xu, F.; Grunewald, J. B.; Ma, X.; Zhao, Y.; Gu, S.; Yan, Y. All-Soluble All-Iron Aqueous Redox-Flow Battery. ACS Energy Lett. 2016, 1, 89– 93,  DOI: 10.1021/acsenergylett.6b00049
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        126
        All-Soluble All-Iron Aqueous Redox-Flow Battery
        Gong, Ke; Xu, Fei; Grunewald, Jonathan B.; Ma, Xiaoya; Zhao, Yun; Gu, Shuang; Yan, Yushan
        ACS Energy Letters (2016), 1 (1), 89-93CODEN: AELCCP; ISSN:2380-8195. (American Chemical Society)
        The rapid growth of intermittent renewable energy (e.g., wind and solar) demands low-cost and large-scale energy storage systems for smooth and reliable power output, where redox-flow batteries (RFBs) could find their niche. The authors introduce the 1st all-sol. all-iron RFB based on iron as the same redox-active element but with different coordination chemistries in alk. aq. system. The adoption of the same redox-active element largely alleviates the challenging problem of cross-contamination of metal ions in RFBs that use two redox-active elements. An all-sol. all-iron RFB is constructed by combining an iron-triethanolamine redox pair (i.e., [Fe(TEOA)OH]-/[Fe(TEOA)(OH)]2-) and an iron-cyanide redox pair (i.e., Fe(CN)63-/Fe(CN)64-), creating 1.34 V of formal cell voltage. Good performance and stability were demonstrated, after addressing some challenges, including the crossover of the ligand agent. As exemplified by the all-sol. all-iron flow battery, combining redox pairs of the same redox-active element with different coordination chemistries could extend the spectrum of RFBs.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XntVOgsLw%253D&md5=d81740112eb308b6ddfa7c772a5751e8
      127. 127
        DeBruler, C.; Hu, B.; Moss, J.; Luo, J.; Liu, T. L. A sulfonate-functionalized viologen enabling neutral cation exchange, aqueous organic redox flow batteries toward renewable energy storage. ACS Energy Lett. 2018, 3, 663– 668,  DOI: 10.1021/acsenergylett.7b01302
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        127
        A Sulfonate-Functionalized Viologen Enabling Neutral Cation Exchange, Aqueous Organic Redox Flow Batteries toward Renewable Energy Storage
        DeBruler, Camden; Hu, Bo; Moss, Jared; Luo, Jian; Liu, T. Leo
        ACS Energy Letters (2018), 3 (3), 663-668CODEN: AELCCP; ISSN:2380-8195. (American Chemical Society)
        Redox flow batteries using synthetically tunable and resource abundant org. mols. have gained increasing attention for large-scale energy storage. Herein we report a sulfonate-functionalized viologen mol., 1,1'-bis(3-sulfonatopropyl)-4,4'-bipyridinium, (SPr)2V, as an anolyte in neutral aq. org. redox flow batteries (AORFBs) functioning through a cation charge-transfer mechanism. Demonstrated (SPr)2V/KI AORFBs manifested high current performance from 40 to 100 mA/cm2 with up to 71% energy efficiency. In extended cycling studies, the (SPr)2V/KI redox flow battery delivered stable cycling performance at 60 mA/cm2, up to 67% energy efficiency, and 99.99% capacity retention per cycle. D. functional theory modeling of the electrostatic charge surface of (SPr)2V and its charged state, [(SPr)2V]-1, suggests charge repulsion and size exclusion enable their compatibility with a cation exchange membrane. The present findings expand the battery design of neutral viologen AORFBs and represent an attractive RFB technol. for sustainable and benign renewable energy storage.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXis12ntb4%253D&md5=03f8926e91141deeba217b03db9b98d5

        Huang, J. H.; Yang, Z.; Murugesan, V.; Walter, E.; Hollas, A.; Pan, B. F.; Assary, R. S.; Shkrob, I. A.; Wei, X. L.; Zhang, Z. C. Spatially Constrained Organic Diquat Anolyte for Stable Aqueous Flow Batteries. ACS Energy Lett. 2018, 3, 2533– 2538,  DOI: 10.1021/acsenergylett.8b01550
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        128
        Spatially Constrained Organic Diquat Anolyte for Stable Aqueous Flow Batteries
        Huang, Jinhua; Yang, Zheng; Murugesan, Vijayakumar; Walter, Eric; Hollas, Aaron; Pan, Baofei; Assary, Rajeev S.; Shkrob, Ilya A.; Wei, Xiaoliang; Zhang, Zhengcheng
        ACS Energy Letters (2018), 3 (10), 2533-2538CODEN: AELCCP; ISSN:2380-8195. (American Chemical Society)
        Redox-active org. materials (ROMs) are becoming increasingly attractive for use in redox flow batteries as promising alternatives to traditional inorg. counterparts. However, the reported ROMs are often accompanied by challenges, including poor soly. and stability. Here, we demonstrate that the commonly used diquat herbicides, with solubilities of >2M in aq. electrolytes, can be used as stable anolyte materials in org. flow batteries. When coupled with a ferrocene-derived catholyte, the flow cells with the diquat anolyte demonstrate long galvanic cycling with high capacity retention. The mechanistic underpinnings of this remarkable stability are attributed to the improved π-conjugation that originated from the near-planar mol. conformations of the spatially constrained 2,2'-bipyridyl rings, suggesting a viable structural engineering strategy for designing stable org. materials.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXhslyrs7fF&md5=d6d3f7fa188f597d6cc5aa60ccf79c98

        DeBruler, C.; Hu, B.; Moss, J.; Liu, X. A.; Luo, J. A.; Sun, Y. J.; Liu, T. L. Designer Two-Electron Storage Viologen Anolyte Materials for Neutral Aqueous Organic Redox Flow Batteries. Chem. 2017, 3, 961– 978,  DOI: 10.1016/j.chempr.2017.11.001
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        129
        Designer Two-Electron Storage Viologen Anolyte Materials for Neutral Aqueous Organic Redox Flow Batteries
        DeBruler, Camden; Hu, Bo; Moss, Jared; Liu, Xuan; Luo, Jian; Sun, Yujie; Liu, T. Leo
        Chem (2017), 3 (6), 961-978CODEN: CHEMVE; ISSN:2451-9294. (Cell Press)
        Aq. org. redox flow batteries (AORFBs) are highly attractive for large-scale energy storage because redox-active org. mols. are synthetically tunable, sustainable, and potentially low cost. Here, we show that rational mol. engineering yielded a series of two-electron storage viologen mols. as anolyte materials for AORFBs. In neutral NaCl solns., these viologen anolytes have a theor. capacity of up to 96.5 Ah/L in H2O and exhibit a redn. potential as low as -0.78 V vs. normal hydrogen electrode. The neutral aq. flow batteries with two two-electron storage viologen mols. delivered a cell voltage of up to 1.38 V and outstanding battery performance, including a power d. of up to 130 mW/cm2, capacity retention of up to 99.99% per cycle, and energy efficiency of up to 65% at 60 mA/cm2. D. functional theory calcns. revealed that the 1e- and 2e- reduced redox states of these mols. were stabilized by the high charge delocalization of their frontier SOMO or HOMO.

        Improved radical stability of viologen anolytes in aqueous organic redox flow batteries
        Hu, Bo; Tang, Yijie; Luo, Jian; Grove, Grant; Guo, Yisong; Liu, T. Leo
        Chemical Communications (Cambridge, United Kingdom) (2018), 54 (50), 6871-6874CODEN: CHCOFS; ISSN:1359-7345. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A high voltage (1.38 V) total org. aq. redox flow battery is reported using 1,1'-bis[3-(trimethylammonio)propyl]-4,4'-bipyridinium tetrachloride ((NPr)2V) as an anolyte and 4-trimethylammonium-TEMPO chloride (NMe-TEMPO) as a catholyte. The exceptional radical stability of [(NPr)2V]+̇ enabled the flow battery in achieving 97.48% capacity retention for 500 cycles and a power d. of 128.2 mW cm-2.

        Anion-exchange membranes in electrochemical energy systems
        Varcoe, John R.; Atanassov, Plamen; Dekel, Dario R.; Herring, Andrew M.; Hickner, Michael A.; Kohl, Paul. A.; Kucernak, Anthony R.; Mustain, William E.; Nijmeijer, Kitty; Scott, Keith; Xu, Tongwen; Zhuang, Lin
        Energy & Environmental Science (2014), 7 (10), 3135-3191CODEN: EESNBY; ISSN:1754-5706. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A review. This article provides an up-to-date perspective on the use of anion-exchange membranes in fuel cells, electrolyzers, redox flow batteries, reverse electrodialysis cells, and bioelectrochem. systems (e.g. microbial fuel cells). The aim is to highlight key concepts, misconceptions, the current state-of-the-art, technol. and scientific limitations, and the future challenges (research priorities) related to the use of anion-exchange membranes in these energy technologies. All the refs. that the authors deemed relevant, and were available on the web by the manuscript submission date (30th Apr. 2014), are included.

        Zhu, Y.; Yang, F.; Niu, Z.; Wu, H.; He, Y.; Zhu, H.; Ye, J.; Zhao, Y.; Zhang, X. Enhanced cyclability of organic redox flow batteries enabled by an artificial bipolar molecule in neutral aqueous electrolyte. J. Power Sources 2019, 417, 83– 89,  DOI: 10.1016/j.jpowsour.2019.02.021
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        132
        Enhanced cyclability of organic redox flow batteries enabled by an artificial bipolar molecule in neutral aqueous electrolyte
        Zhu, Yingzhong; Yang, Fan; Niu, Zhihui; Wu, Huaxi; He, Yan; Zhu, Huifang; Ye, Jing; Zhao, Yu; Zhang, Xiaohong
        Journal of Power Sources (2019), 417 (), 83-89CODEN: JPSODZ; ISSN:0378-7753. (Elsevier B.V.)
        Org. redox flow batteries receive increasing interest for large-scale elec. energy storage owing to the structural diversity and elemental abundance of org. compds. However, their implementation is challenged by the cyclability, which is an order of magnitude lower than traditional redox flow batteries using inorg. redox couples. The unsatisfactory cyclability mainly arises from electrolyte contamination and irreversible losses of active material in the electrolyte. To address such issues, a highly water-sol. artificial bipolar mol. contg. cathode-active ferrocene moiety and anode-active bipyridinium moiety is realized and used as the sole active material in a sym. org. redox flow cell. Owing to the good reversibility, min. electrolyte contamination, and stability of the synthesized mol., the demonstrated cell boosts the cyclability to 4000 cycles with capacity retention of ∼75% at 100% depth of discharge, which fills in the gap of cyclability between org. redox flow batteries and conventional redox flow batteries.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1MXivF2jsb4%253D&md5=f218f0a9c4baa42e3a8324795f72bab4
      133. 133
        Yu, X. W.; Manthiram, A. A strategically managed rechargeable battery system with a neutral methyl viologen anolyte and an acidic air-cathode enabled by a mediator-ion solid electrolyte. Sustainable Energy & Fuels 2018, 2, 1452– 1457,  DOI: 10.1039/C8SE00227D
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        133
        A strategically managed rechargeable battery system with a neutral methyl viologen anolyte and an acidic air-cathode enabled by a mediator-ion solid electrolyte
        Yu, Xingwen; Manthiram, Arumugam
        Sustainable Energy & Fuels (2018), 2 (7), 1452-1457CODEN: SEFUA7; ISSN:2398-4902. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        Redox flow batteries with org. electrode materials are attracting much attention. Previous research efforts have been focusing on liq.-phase electrodes on both the anode and cathode sides. Since batteries based on air cathodes can provide immense advantages, coupling a liq. org. electrode with a gaseous air cathode could offer multiple benefits in terms of cost, safety, and energy d. Herein we present a liq.-gaseous battery system with an aq. Me viologen (MV) anode and an air cathode. However, under the traditional battery operation principle with the same electrolyte at the anode and cathode, the resulting MV-air battery will not be able to provide a reasonable voltage for practical applications. In this study, the cell voltage of the MV-air chem. is strategically manipulated by using an acidic cathode electrolyte (catholyte) and a neutral anode electrolyte (anolyte). To operate a battery with different electrolytes at the anode and cathode, a sodium-ion (Na+-ion) conductive solid-state electrolyte (Na-SSE) membrane is employed to phys. and elec. sep. the two electrodes. The shuttling of sodium ions via the Na-SSE balances the ionic charge transfer between the two electrodes and sustains the redox reactions at the air cathode and the MV anode.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXhtVGgur3F&md5=099fdb981906c0914469d89b6013aec5

        Poly(boron-dipyrromethene)-A Redox-Active Polymer Class for Polymer Redox-Flow Batteries
        Winsberg, Jan; Hagemann, Tino; Muench, Simon; Friebe, Christian; Haeupler, Bernhard; Janoschka, Tobias; Morgenstern, Sabine; Hager, Martin D.; Schubert, Ulrich S.
        Chemistry of Materials (2016), 28 (10), 3401-3405CODEN: CMATEX; ISSN:0897-4756. (American Chemical Society)
        The use of boron-dipyrromethene (BODIPY) as active group for the charge storage process in a battery application is reported. Two BODIPY-contg. copolymers were synthesized and electrochem. characterized. The polymers feature redox processes at 0.7 V and -1.5 V vs. AgNO3/Ag, which enable the application in a redox-flow battery setup.

      135. 135
        Winsberg, J.; Janoschka, T.; Morgenstern, S.; Hagemann, T.; Muench, S.; Hauffman, G.; Gohy, J. F.; Hager, M. D.; Schubert, U. S. Poly(TEMPO)/Zinc Hybrid-Flow Battery: A Novel, “Green,” High Voltage, and Safe Energy Storage System. Adv. Mater. 2016, 28, 2238– 2243,  DOI: 10.1002/adma.201505000
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        135
        Poly(TEMPO)/Zinc Hybrid-Flow Battery: A Novel, "Green," High Voltage, and Safe Energy Storage System
        Winsberg, Jan; Janoschka, Tobias; Morgenstern, Sabine; Hagemann, Tino; Muench, Simon; Hauffman, Guillaume; Gohy, Jean-Francois; Hager, Martin D.; Schubert, Ulrich S.
        Advanced Materials (Weinheim, Germany) (2016), 28 (11), 2238-2243CODEN: ADVMEW; ISSN:0935-9648. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        A novel type of zinc hybrid-flow battery was successfully implemented. The application of several TEMPO-contg. polymers, as active cathode material, leads to significant improvements concerning corrosion and environmental impact compared to already known zinc-halogen hybrid-flow batteries. The different applied catholytes comprised P(TEMPO-co-PEGMA)s, synthesized via RAFT polymn. and P(TEMPO-co-METAC), which was designed particularly for aq. solns. To the best of our knowledge, it is the first reported type of flow battery, which enables a stable potential window of up to 2 V in aq. media, without utilization of toxic and expensive heavy metals. Furthermore, a contamination with oxygen is unproblematic rendering the expensive inertization of the battery unnecessary. In carbonate-based electrolytes, high-energy densities of 8.1 Wh/L were achieved, while water based electrolytes allow application of higher current densities of up to 20 mA/cm2 , as well as a stable energy efficiency of over 80%. Furthermore, water-based TEMPO/zinc HFBs feature an elevated OCV of 1.7 V compared to org.-based ones with an OCV of 1.3 V. Both systems showed very good long-term stability of 500 and 1,000 consecutive charging and discharging cycles, resp. When comparing the investigated TEMPO-copolymers with one another, P(TEMPO-co-PEGMA)s are the copolymers of choice for poly(TEMPO)/zinc hybrid-flow batteries. The reported poly(TEMPO)/zinc HFB features high applicable current densities, compared to previously reported TEMPO contg. RFBs, low acquisition costs for both active materials as well as the membrane. The robustness of the employed redox couples leads to high cycle stabilities and, in general, to low intrinsic hazards. This enables the suitability as energy storage system in large scales.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28Xhtl2nu74%253D&md5=ddffd5922a9a7192e6eb62fd80603b95
      136. 136
        Winsberg, J.; Muench, S.; Hagemann, T.; Morgenstern, S.; Janoschka, T.; Billing, M.; Schacher, F. H.; Hauffman, G.; Gohy, J.-F.; Hoeppener, S.; Hager, M. D.; Schubert, U. S. Polymer/zinc hybrid-flow battery using block copolymer micelles featuring a TEMPO corona as catholyte. Polym. Chem. 2016, 7, 1711– 1718,  DOI: 10.1039/C5PY02036K
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        136
        Polymer/zinc hybrid-flow battery using block copolymer micelles featuring a TEMPO corona as catholyte
        Winsberg, Jan; Muench, Simon; Hagemann, Tino; Morgenstern, Sabine; Janoschka, Tobias; Billing, Mark; Schacher, Felix H.; Hauffman, Guillaume; Gohy, Jean-Francois; Hoeppener, Stephanie; Hager, Martin D.; Schubert, Ulrich S.
        Polymer Chemistry (2016), 7 (9), 1711-1718CODEN: PCOHC2; ISSN:1759-9962. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A well-defined block copolymer was applied in a semi-org. polymer hybrid-flow battery (pHFB). A 2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidinyl-N-oxyl (TEMPO) contg. polymer was utilized as cathode active material. Micellar structures of the active material were achieved by utilizing a diblock copolymer composed of a polar poly(TEMPO methacrylate) (PTMA) and an unpolar poly(styrene) (PS) block, which enables the formation of core-corona micelles in org. carbonates. The synthesized PTMA-b-PS was electrochem. investigated and subsequently utilized as catholyte in polymer/Zn pHFBs. The constructed flow batteries feature an excellent cycling stability of 1000 consecutive charge/discharge cycles with 95% retention of initial discharge capacity and a stable voltage range of 2 V. Further, the charging process leads to slight changes in the micellar structure combined with an increased soly.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

      138. 138
        Milshtein, J. D.; Su, L.; Liou, C.; Badel, A. F.; Brushett, F. R. Voltammetry study of quinoxaline in aqueous electrolytes. Electrochim. Acta 2015, 180, 695– 704,  DOI: 10.1016/j.electacta.2015.07.063
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        138
        Voltammetry study of quinoxaline in aqueous electrolytes
        Milshtein, Jarrod D.; Su, Liang; Liou, Catherine; Badel, Andres F.; Brushett, Fikile R.
        Electrochimica Acta (2015), 180 (), 695-704CODEN: ELCAAV; ISSN:0013-4686. (Elsevier Ltd.)
        Org. compds. have recently received considerable attention as active materials in redox flow batteries (RFBs) due to their good electrochem. reversibility, high theor. energy densities, and promise for low cost prodn. Until now, org. active material candidates for aq. RFBs have been limited to the quinone family, a set of arom.-derived org. mols., distinguished by an even no. of ketone (R-C(=O)-R') groups. This work aims to elucidate and optimize the electrochem. behavior of quinoxaline, an org. mol. consisting of fused benzene and pyrazine rings, in aq. electrolytes. More than 30 electrolytes are screened by cyclic voltammetry, and the five most promising electrolytes are investigated further using rotating disk voltammetry. Electrochem. behavior of quinoxaline shows pH dependent thermodn. and reaction mechanisms, while chloride-contg. supporting electrolytes greatly enhance soly. This study sheds light on the promising characteristics of quinoxaline as a low potential compd. for aq. RFBs; quinoxaline has a redox potential of E° ≈ -0.02 V vs. RHE, is sol. up to ∼4.5 M in water, exhibits a two-electron transfer capability, and possesses a low mol. wt. (130.15 g mol-1), resulting in a theor. capacity of 410 mAh g-1.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXhsFertLbE&md5=9ebec342c451af5c3e2280f97deaada7
      139. 139
        Orita, A.; Verde, M. G.; Sakai, M.; Meng, Y. S. A biomimetic redox flow battery based on flavin mononucleotide. Nat. Commun. 2016, 7, 13230,  DOI: 10.1038/ncomms13230
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        139
        A biomimetic redox flow battery based on flavin mononucleotide
        Orita, Akihiro; Verde, Michael G.; Sakai, Masanori; Meng, Ying Shirley
        Nature Communications (2016), 7 (), 13230CODEN: NCAOBW; ISSN:2041-1723. (Nature Publishing Group)
        The versatility in design of redox flow batteries makes them apt to efficiently store energy in large-scale applications at low cost. The discovery of inexpensive org. electroactive materials for use in aq. flow battery electrolytes is highly attractive, but is thus far limited. Here we report on a flow battery using an aq. electrolyte based on the sodium salt of FMN. Flavins are highly versatile electroactive mols., which catalyze a multitude of redox reactions in biol. systems. We use nicotinamide (vitamin B3) as a hydrotropic agent to enhance the water soly. of FMN. A redox flow battery using FMN neg. and ferrocyanide pos. electrolytes in strong base shows stable cycling performance, with over 99% capacity retention over the course of 100 cycles. We hypothesize that this is enabled due to the oxidized and reduced forms of FMN-Na being stabilized by resonance structures.

        Sevov, C. S.; Hendriks, K. H.; Sanford, M. S. Low-Potential Pyridinium Anolyte for Aqueous Redox Flow Batteries. J. Phys. Chem. C 2017, 121, 24376– 24380,  DOI: 10.1021/acs.jpcc.7b06247
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        140
        Low-Potential Pyridinium Anolyte for Aqueous Redox Flow Batteries
        Sevov, Christo S.; Hendriks, Koen H.; Sanford, Melanie S.
        Journal of Physical Chemistry C (2017), 121 (44), 24376-24380CODEN: JPCCCK; ISSN:1932-7447. (American Chemical Society)
        Aq. redox flow batteries (RFBs) can serve as inexpensive grid-scale energy storage devices. A key challenge for developing these systems is identifying storage materials that undergo reversible redox events at potentials near the voltaic limits of aq. media. This work details the development of a benzoylpyridinium-based anolyte for this application. A combination of electrochem. and spectroscopic studies guided the selection of a supporting electrolyte to mitigate anolyte-catalyzed proton redn. at the low potentials. These insights were used to achieve stable one-electron cycling with KOH as the support in both a H cell and in a lab.-scale flow cell. In the latter expt., cycling vs. iron ferrocyanide afforded an aq. RFB with an open-circuit voltage exceeding 1 V.

        Huang, Z. F.; Zhang, P.; Gao, X. P.; Henkensmeier, D.; Passerini, S.; Chen, R. Y. Unlocking Simultaneously the Temperature and Electrochemical Windows of Aqueous Phthalocyanine Electrolytes. Acs Applied Energy Materials 2019, 2, 3773– 3779,  DOI: 10.1021/acsaem.9b00467
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        141
        Unlocking Simultaneously the Temperature and Electrochemical Windows of Aqueous Phthalocyanine Electrolytes
        Huang, Zhifeng; Zhang, Peng; Gao, Xinpei; Henkensmeier, Dirk; Passerini, Stefano; Chen, Ruiyong
        ACS Applied Energy Materials (2019), 2 (5), 3773-3779CODEN: AAEMCQ; ISSN:2574-0962. (American Chemical Society)
        The change from org. solvents to aq. solvents for safe and robust battery electrolytes is desirable for electrochem. energy storage. Thermodynamically, water has an electrochem. stability window of 1.23 V, and pure water freezes at 0 °C. Such properties clearly restrict the high-voltage applications and temp. adaptability of aq. electrolytes. Herein, we report an aq. supporting electrolyte contg. imidazolium chloride, showing unprecedented large temp. and electrochem. windows. Thermal anal. over -80 to 80 °C shows such an aq. electrolyte to be free of transition events of icing and phase changes. X-ray scattering results of these aq. solns. in the presence of active materials reveal the pivotal role of imidazolium chloride to preserve the liq. phase at rather low temps. Metal phthalocyanines with electroactive org. ligand rings and multi-electron-transfer reactions at low neg. potentials (-0.2 to -1.6 V vs Ag) are demonstrated in water-based anolytes for redox flow batteries for the first time over a broad temp. range.

        Hong, J.; Kim, K. Neutral Red and Ferroin as Reversible and Rapid Redox Materials for Redox Flow Batteries. ChemSusChem 2018, 11, 1866– 1872,  DOI: 10.1002/cssc.201800303
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        143
        Neutral Red and Ferroin as Reversible and Rapid Redox Materials for Redox Flow Batteries
        Hong, Jeehoon; Kim, Ketack
        ChemSusChem (2018), 11 (11), 1866-1872CODEN: CHEMIZ; ISSN:1864-5631. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        Neutral red and ferroin are used as redox indicators (RINs) in potentiometric titrns. The rapid response and reversibility that are prerequisites for RINs are also desirable properties for the active materials in redox flow batteries (RFBs). This study describes the electrochem. properties of ferroin and neutral red as a redox pair. The rapid reaction rates of the RINs allow a cell to run at a rate of 4 C with 89 % capacity retention after the 100th cycle. The diffusion coeffs., electrode reaction rates, and solubilities of the RINs were detd. The electron-transfer rate consts. of ferroin and neutral red are 0.11 and 0.027 cm s-1, resp., which are greater than those of the components of all-vanadium and Zn/Br2 cells.

        McCormick, D. B.; Fory, W. Base-Catalyzed Hydrolysis of Flavins - Effect of Amines and Particular Role of Position 3. J. Pharm. Sci. 1968, 57, 841– 844,  DOI: 10.1002/jps.2600570526
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        146
        Base-catalyzed hydrolysis of flavines. Effect of amines and the particular role of Position 3
        McCormick, Donald B.; Foery, Werner
        Journal of Pharmaceutical Sciences (1968), 57 (5), 841-4CODEN: JPMSAE; ISSN:0022-3549.
        The base-catalyzed hydrolysis of flavines was investigated in 50% water-MeOH with excess NaOH or excess amines at different temps. Rate consts. for the pseudo first-order cleavage of the pyrimidine portion of the isoalloxazine systems were measured and with NaOH shown to increase from lumiflavine to 3-ethyllumiflavine to 3-carboxyamido(phenylalanyl)lumiflavine. With amines, the size as well as basicity is of prime importance since the general order in efficacy of the nucleophile for hydrolysis of flavines is EtNH2 > Et2NH > Et3N > PhCH2NH2 > Bu3N. In general, alkylation of the 3-imino function of the flavine increases its lability because of inability to ionize and undergo resonance stabilization of the anionic tautomers. Moreover, the special case where a 3-carboxamido function is present allows intramol. polarization, via H bonding of the amide H to 4-carbonyl O which causes a marked increase in hydrolysis rate in NaOH. From the temp. dependencies of the rates of hydrolysis, the calcd. values for energies of activation indicate a decrease expected upon 3-alkylation and further upon intramol. enhancement with the 3-carboxyamido group. The calcd. values for entropies of activation are large and neg. in accord with considerable loss of degrees of freedom in the activated complexes formed in the bimol. mechanism.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaF1cXksFWhur8%253D&md5=42d0c38e27ded216311e531e26fb72e4
      147. 147
        Grajek, H.; Zurkowska, G.; Drabent, R.; Bojarski, C. The structure of the flavomononucleotide dimer. Biochim. Biophys. Acta, Gen. Subj. 1986, 881, 241– 247,  DOI: 10.1016/0304-4165(86)90010-3
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        147
        The structure of the flavomononucleotide dimer
        Grajek, Hanna; Zurkowska, Grazyna; Drabent, Regina; Bojarski, Czeslaw
        Biochimica et Biophysica Acta, General Subjects (1986), 881 (2), 241-7CODEN: BBGSB3; ISSN:0304-4165.
        Structural parameters of the FMN dimer in water and glycerin-water soln. have been established on the basis of spectroscopic studies and the Kasha theory. A parallel-plane dimer model is proposed in which the monomer units are arranged face-to-face. For the FMN dimer in water, the distance (R) between the planes of monomer units is 3.5 Å, and the angle αI between the moments of transition S2 ← S0 (absorption band I) and the angle αII between the moments of transition S2 ← S0 (band II) of monomer units are 71 and 0°, resp. From the mentioned orientation of absorption transition moments of FMN monomer units in the dimer, a conclusion may be drawn that the angle, .vphi., between the transition moments S1 ← S0 and S2 ← S0 is 36°. This orientation is consistent with the results obtained by L. B. A. Johansson et al. (1979) for FMN mols. in lamellar liq. crystals. Similar R, αI, and αII values were obtained for the FMN dimer in the water-glycerin soln.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        Darling, R. M.; Perry, M. L. Half-Cell, Steady-State Flow-Battery Experiments. ECS Trans. 2013, 53, 31– 38,  DOI: 10.1149/05307.0031ecst
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        148
        Half-cell, steady-state flow-battery experiments
        Darling, Robert M.; Perry, Mike L.
        ECS Transactions (2013), 53 (7, Stationary and Large Scale Electrical Energy Storage 2), 31-38, 8 pp.CODEN: ECSTF8; ISSN:1938-5862. (Electrochemical Society)
        An exptl. approach designed to sep. test the pos. and neg. sides of a redox flow battery is discussed. Circulating a single electrolyte through a cell so that oxidn. occurs on one electrode and redn. occurs on the other electrode eliminates the problem of reactant crossover that occurs when different electrolytes are placed on either side of the cell. This approach allows phenomena assocd. with the pos. and neg. electrode-electrolyte combinations to be studied in isolation. Polarization curves, steady-state potential holds, and potential-cycling expts. are presented as examples of results that can be obtained with this approach. The impact of side reactions on the results is also discussed.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXos1OgsLc%253D&md5=3ede468d91b4917293c36830cbd7c008

        Milshtein, J. D.; Barton, J. L.; Darling, R. M.; Brushett, F. R. 4-acetamido-2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidine-1-oxyl as a model organic redox active compound for nonaqueous flow batteries. J. Power Sources 2016, 327, 151– 159,  DOI: 10.1016/j.jpowsour.2016.06.125
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        149
        4-acetamido-2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidine-1-oxyl as a model organic redox active compound for nonaqueous flow batteries
        Milshtein, Jarrod D.; Barton, John L.; Darling, Robert M.; Brushett, Fikile R.
        Journal of Power Sources (2016), 327 (), 151-159CODEN: JPSODZ; ISSN:0378-7753. (Elsevier B.V.)
        Nonaq. redox flow batteries (NAqRFBs) that utilize redox active org. mols. are an emerging energy storage concept with the possibility of meeting grid storage requirements. Sporadic and uneven advances in mol. discovery and development, however, have stymied efforts to quantify the performance characteristics of nonaq. redox electrolytes and flow cells. A need exists for archetypal redox couples, with well-defined electrochem. properties, high soly. in relevant electrolytes, and broad availability, to serve as probe mols. This work investigates the 4-acetamido-2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidine-1-oxyl (AcNH-TEMPO) redox pair for such an application. We report the physicochem. and electrochem. properties of the reduced and oxidized compds. at dil. concns. for electroanal., as well as moderate-to-high concns. for RFB applications. Changes in cond., viscosity, and UV-vis absorbance as a function of state-of-charge are quantified. Cyclic voltammetry investigates the redox potential, reversibility, and diffusion coeffs. of dil. solns., while sym. flow cell cycling dets. the stability of the AcNH-TEMPO redox pair over long expt. times. Finally, single electrolyte flow cell studies demonstrate the utility of this redox couple as a platform chem. for benchmarking NAqRFB performance.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28Xht1ahsrrO&md5=85609d40b3c4ca7a403aafde01b28f4a

        Milshtein, J. D.; Kaur, A. P.; Casselman, M. D.; Kowalski, J. A.; Modekrutti, S.; Zhang, P. L.; Harsha Attanayake, N.; Elliott, C. F.; Parkin, S. R.; Risko, C.; Brushett, F. R.; Odom, S. A. High current density, long duration cycling of soluble organic active species for non-aqueous redox flow batteries. Energy Environ. Sci. 2016, 9, 3531– 3543,  DOI: 10.1039/C6EE02027E
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        150
        High current density, long duration cycling of soluble organic active species for non-aqueous redox flow batteries
        Milshtein, Jarrod D.; Kaur, Aman Preet; Casselman, Matthew D.; Kowalski, Jeffrey A.; Modekrutti, Subrahmanyam; Zhang, Peter L.; Harsha Attanayake, N.; Elliott, Corrine F.; Parkin, Sean R.; Risko, Chad; Brushett, Fikile R.; Odom, Susan A.
        Energy & Environmental Science (2016), 9 (11), 3531-3543CODEN: EESNBY; ISSN:1754-5706. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        Non-aq. redox flow batteries (NAqRFBs) employing redox-active org. mols. show promise to meet requirements for grid energy storage. Here, we combine the rational design of org. mols. with flow cell engineering to boost NAqRFB performance. We synthesize two highly sol. phenothiazine derivs., N-(2-methoxyethyl)phenothiazine (MEPT) and N-[2-(2-methoxyethoxy)ethyl]phenothiazine (MEEPT), via a one-step synthesis from inexpensive precursors. Synthesis and isolation of the radical-cation salts permit UV-vis decay studies that illustrate the high stability of these open-shell species. Cyclic voltammetry and bulk electrolysis expts. reveal the promising electrochem. properties of MEPT and MEEPT under dil. conditions. A high performance non-aq. flow cell, employing interdigitated flow fields and carbon paper electrodes, is engineered and demonstrated; polarization and impedance studies quantify the cell's low area-specific resistance (3.2-3.3 Ω cm2). We combine the most sol. deriv., MEEPT, and its tetrafluoroborate radical-cation salt in the flow cell for sym. cycling, evincing a c.d. of 100 mA cm-2 with undetectable capacity fade over 100 cycles. This coincident high c.d. and capacity retention is unprecedented in NAqRFB literature.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XhsFWlsrrI&md5=51155c9921b6ba9da123d44542a8675b
      151. 151
        Drazevic, E.; Szabo, C.; Konya, D.; Lund, T.; Wedege, K.; Bentien, A. Investigation of Tetramorpholinohydroquinone as a Potential Catholyte in a Flow Battery. ACS Appl. Energy Mater. 2019, 2, 4745– 4754,  DOI: 10.1021/acsaem.9b00351
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        151
        Investigation of Tetramorpholinohydroquinone as a Potential Catholyte in a Flow Battery
        Drazevic, Emil; Szabo, Csaba; Konya, Denes; Lund, Torben; Wedege, Kristina; Bentien, Anders
        ACS Applied Energy Materials (2019), 2 (7), 4745-4754CODEN: AAEMCQ; ISSN:2574-0962. (American Chemical Society)
        Redox flow batteries (RFB) based on org. redox active species have low-cost potential for large-scale elec. energy storage. Currently, there are a range of org. mols. as candidates for the neg. side of the RFB: e.g., anthraquinones and alloxazines. However, for the pos. side there are no obvious org. mols. mainly because of stability that is too low and to a lesser extent a low std. potential. Currently, a stable performance was achieved only with inorg. or organo-inorg. species at the pos. side: e.g., Br, ferricyanide, and H2O-sol. derivs. of ferrocene. Previous attempts to use hydroquinones at the pos. side, such as 4,5-dibenzoquinone-1,3-benzenedisulfonate, or H2O-sol. derivations of 2,2,6,6-tetramethyl-1-piperidinyloxy resulted in unstable battery performance. From the available literature it appears as if unsubstituted and partially unsubstituted hydroquinones are not stable in H2O. For this reason a new fully substituted hydroquinone was specifically designed and examd. for the pos. side of the org. RFB in a sym. RFB setup. It has 4 fully protonated morpholino groups, a soly. of 2 M (107 Ah/L) in H2O, and a formal redox potential of 0.89 VNHE; however, its performance is highly dependent on the pH and the electrolyte compn.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1MXhtF2gsbjE&md5=6bfa4c840d963fc085897bae8a57b1a0
      152. 152
        Hu, B.; Luo, J.; Hu, M.; Yuan, B.; Liu, T. L. A pH-Neutral, Metal-Free Aqueous Organic Redox Flow Battery Employing an Ammonium Anthraquinone Anolyte. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2019, 58, 16629– 16636,  DOI: 10.1002/anie.201907934
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        152
        A pH-Neutral, Metal-Free Aqueous Organic Redox Flow Battery Employing an Ammonium Anthraquinone Anolyte
        Hu, Bo; Luo, Jian; Hu, Maowei; Yuan, Bing; Liu, T. Leo
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2019), 58 (46), 16629-16636CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        Redox-active anthraquinone mols. represent promising anolyte materials in aq. org. redox flow batteries (AORFBs). However, the chem. stability issue and corrosion nature of anthraquinone-based anolytes in reported acidic and alk. AORFBs constitute a roadblock for their practical applications in energy storage. A feasible strategy to overcome these issues is migrating to pH-neutral conditions and employing sol. AQDS salts. Here, we report the 9,10-anthraquinone-2,7-disulfonic diammonium salt (AQDS(NH4)2) as an anolyte material for pH-neutral AORFBs with soly. of 1.9M in water, which is >3 times that of the corresponding Na salt. Paired with an NH4I catholyte, the resulting pH-neutral AORFB with an energy d. of 12.5 Wh/L displayed outstanding cycling stability over 300 cycles. Even at the pH-neutral condition, the AQDS(NH4)2/NH4I AORFB delivered an impressive energy efficiency of 70.6% at 60 mA/cm2 and a high power d. of 91.5 mW/cm2 at 100% SOC. This AQDS(NH4)2 flow battery chem. opens a new avenue to apply anthraquinone mols. in developing low-cost and benign pH-neutral flow batteries for scalable energy storage.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1MXhslOgsr7O&md5=e2ce513c39aae486890d40ed514675ec

        Huskinson, B.; Marshak, M. P.; Gerhardt, M. R.; Aziz, M. J. Cycling of a Quinone-Bromide Flow Battery for Large-Scale Electrochemical Energy Storage. ECS Trans. 2014, 61, 27– 30,  DOI: 10.1149/06137.0027ecst
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        153
        Cycling of a quinone-bromide flow battery for large-scale electrochemical energy storage
        Huskinson, Brian; Marshak, Michael P.; Gerhardt, Michael R.; Aziz, Michael J.
        ECS Transactions (2014), 61 (37, Stationary and Large Scale Electrical Energy Storage Systems 4), 27-30CODEN: ECSTF8; ISSN:1938-5862. (Electrochemical Society)
        We have demonstrated the performance of an aq. redox flow battery composed of a neg. electrode consisting of a redox couple between anthraquinone di-sulfonate and its corresponding hydroquinone, and a pos. electrode consisting of a redox couple between hydrobromic acid and bromine. The peak power d. is approx. 0.6 W/cm2. After 750 deep cycles, the av. discharge capacity retention is 99.84% per cycle and the av. current efficiency is 98.35%.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XhslWntL7J&md5=f439543404997048f4a1bc2fe5836bcb
      154. 154
        Asperger, S. Kinetics of the decomposition of potassium ferrocyanide in ultra-violet light. Trans. Faraday Soc. 1952, 48, 617– 624,  DOI: 10.1039/TF9524800617
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        154
        Kinetics of the decomposition of potassium ferrocyanide in ultraviolet light
        Asperger, S.
        Transactions of the Faraday Society (1952), 48 (), 617-24CODEN: TFSOA4; ISSN:0014-7672.
        The kinetics of both the decompn. and the reverse (thermal) reaction were investigated in presence of air, in N, and in O with a glass electrode for detn. of pH. Oxygen has no influence. The reaction scheme involving the formation of Fe(CN)5.H2O3- is in accord with the expts. The addn. of K3Fe(CN)6 inhibits the reaction. In the light the process has a neg. temp. coeff. (Q10 = 0.7). The energy of activation of the reverse process (reaction between Fe(CN)5.H2O3- and CN-), is about 24 kcal./mole. Fe(CN)5.H2O3- is decompd. by prolonged exposure to light, but this process is very slow. The dependence of the initial velocity of the process on the concn. of the K4Fe(CN)6, however, shows that the decompn. is due not only to the light energy, but also to collisions of mols.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport-cas-org.ezproxy.uky.edu/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaG3sXis1eg&md5=3a9b09452645f74ac4fc445017c8ec36
      155. 155
        Arellano, C. A. P.; Martínez, S. S. Effects of pH on the degradation of aqueous ferricyanide by photolysis and photocatalysis under solar radiation. Sol. Energy Mater. Sol. Cells 2010, 94, 327– 332,  DOI: 10.1016/j.solmat.2009.10.008
        [Crossref], Google Scholar
        There is no corresponding record for this reference.
      156. 156
        Esswein, A. J.; Goeltz, J.; Amadeo, D. High Solubility Iron Hexacyanides. U.S. Patent 13,887,461, 2014.
        Google Scholar
        There is no corresponding record for this reference.
